testing may include num hamburg wheel track testing of compacted bituminous mixtures refer to aashto t num .

samples from reinforced structures may be taken only as approved by the engineer .
num air void system in hardened concrete refer to astm c num. c. include an engineering evaluation based on durability and serviceability relative to the specified product requirements .
this includes expected performance compared to design life .
num dispute resolution procedure for acceptance or verification test results a .
the contractor may dispute the validity of the departments acceptance or verification tests .
num .
the option to dispute the validity of the departments test results is forfeited if laboratory correlation testing is required by specification and is not performed .
b .
contractor disputes will not change the departmentselected option for materials acceptance based on sampling and testing as outlined in the udot materials manual of instruction section num .
num .
quality control results may be used to dispute acceptance test results .
c. the department immediately reviews the submittal when the construction schedule and contractor information indicates that a rejected lot will be affected within num hours by work that may prevent the evaluation correction or removal of the lot in question .
num .
the department may suspend work related to the lot in question if merit is found in the engineering analysis .
d. resolve differences in test results prior to further production of the material type in question .
e. the department and contractor immediately begin to investigate and review the engineering analysis and resolve the dispute if merit is found .
the investigation includes the following .
num .
a test and calculation procedure review .
refer to this section article num .
num .
validation testing as appropriate .
refer to this section article num .
num .
third party testing and review as appropriate .
refer to this section article num .
implementation num materials dispute resolution num num of num january num num f. the department may choose to evaluate the lot using appropriate test methods if significant errors are identified that can not be corrected and the quality of the inplace material is in question .
g. the engineer reviews the analysis and notifies the contractor in writing of their decision .
the notification of rejection includes the following num .
engineering basis for rejecting the contractors analysis including specific points of objection .
num .
department data and analysis to justify department position .
num .
time frame for removal of material or pay adjustment to be applied to the lot .
h. the department will review the contractors schedule and make appropriate adjustments to contract time when significant errors are identified in the departments testing results based on critical path analysis .
refer to section num .
num .
time lost due to a rejected analysis is not credited to the contract time .
i .
the departments response concludes this materials dispute resolution process .
num .
continuing disputes must be addressed and escalated as outlined in section num and the udot and utah agc partnering field guide .
num test and calculation procedure review for disputed acceptance or verification test results a .
the department and contractor immediately begin a review of the acceptance test results when the department concludes the engineering analysis has merit and test procedures or calculations are in question .
the review normally includes the following in an appropriate order num .
a review of all equipment procedures and methods used for sampling splitting and testing .
num .
a review of the department and contractors raw test data and calculations for documentation or calculation errors .
num .
production and testing of additional correlation samples .
num .
crosswitnessing of test procedures by contractor quality control and department personnel .
num .
distribution of any other pertinent information .
num .
discussion of other possible means for variation .
b .
the department corrects the applicable test results and reapplies the acceptance determination and associated payment if equipment issues or errors in calculations or reporting are discovered .
implementation num materials dispute resolution num num of num january num num c. the department evaluates the lot using the original test results if no significant errors are identified .
num validation testing for disputed acceptance or verification test results a. validation testing may be performed by the department as follows num .
department personnel begin retesting on the material remaining from the original department test .
a .
the contractors representative may witness the testing .
b .
the department may perform the validation testing in the departments region or central materials laboratory .
c. retest all samples in the lot .
num .
retesting results are used to validate or invalidate original department result .
a. validation test results may not be used instead of acceptance results .
b .
results within two standard deviations of the original acceptance results are validated .
num use the project acceptance results for the lot in question to determine the standard deviation .
num .
invalidated test results are removed from acceptance lot and the lot is reevaluated based on the reduced sample size .
b .
the department evaluates the lot using the original test results if no samples are invalidated .
num third party testing and review for disputed acceptance or verification test results a .
third party testing may be performed as follows num .
select an independent third party agreed upon by the department and the contractor to witness sample splitting and testing by both the contractor and the department if errors in testing can not be identified .
num .
the independent third party identifies and obtains additional material for splitsample testing .
num .
the independent third party witnesses splitsample testing in the department and contractor laboratories evaluates the test procedures compares the results determines if there are errors and provides a report .
num .
the party responsible for the identified error pays for the services of the independent third party .
b .
the department evaluates the lot using the original testing results if no significant errors are identified .
implementation num materials dispute resolution num num of num january num num num reject material a .
the contractor may request that rejected nonconforming material be left in place at a reduced price .
include an engineering analysis .
b .
the engineer determines whether the lot is to be removed or remain in place and the associated price reduction if other than specified in the contract .

includes the moving of personnel equipment supplies and incidentals to each work site before beginning the work .
b .
includes the establishment of offices buildings and other facilities necessary for the work .
c. includes labor and operations which must be performed before beginning other items under the contract .
d. includes removal of personnel equipment and supplies from each work site at the completion of the work .
e. includes work that is not included with other items under the contract such as cleanup and restoration of disturbed areas .

peak hours peak hours are num a.m. to num a.m. and num p.m. to num p.m. monday through friday unless otherwise defined by the engineer or in the special provision for section num .
b .
traffic slow down an isolated planned event where traffic on a highway is reduced in speed to provide a gap for work to proceed .
num .
examples include the crossing of the highway with heavy equipment or the adjustment of traffic control devices .
c. tprs temporary portable rumble strips an array of num heavy rubber strips that create noise when they are run over and are used to alert drivers to the presence of road construction .

num traffic control requirements a .
meet the following requirements for traffic control and document them in the traffic control plan num .
provide for the safe movement of traffic .
a .

num .

a .

a .

implements the traffic control plan .

remains available num hours a day seven days a week and can be onsite within num minutes of notification .

num .
document the traffic control inspections on a form acceptable to the engineer .
inspect at least four times each day with at least one of the inspections conducted during nighttime hours a .
before beginning of shift b .
at midshift c. halfhour after shift ends and d. at the midpoint of the offshift period .

coordinate project traffic control with emergency services and local law enforcement agencies .

a .
once during daylight hours and once during nighttime hours .

a .
the amount per day by which the contractors compensation will be reduced is calculated using the daily charge for calendar day in the schedule of liquidated damages in table of section num or the contract lump sum bid price for traffic control divided by the number of contract days whichever is greater .

implementation num traffic control num page num of num january num num num limitation of operations a .
traffic slow down num .
notify and obtain approval from the department and law enforcement a minimum of num hours prior to slow down .
num .
use a highway patrol trooper or other law enforcement officer in a marked vehicle with overhead flashing lights to conduct the slow down .
num .
use the officer in the marked vehicle to slow down one or two lanes .
a .
use in any combination either contractorsupplied vehicles equipped with overhead amber flashing lights or additional officers in marked vehicles at the rate of one vehicle per lane thereafter for all lanes of the highway to affect the traffic slow down .
num .
additional vehicles as described in this article may be used in the traffic slow down to supplement the law enforcement vehicle when required by the officer .
num .
the duration of any traffic slow down is not to exceed five minutes or as approved by the region traffic engineer and communicated through the engineer .
num temporary portable rumble strips tprs a .
clean road surface with broom or blower to remove all gravel sand dust or other debris .
b .
assemble modular pieces into strips that match the width of the travel lane as closely as possible .
num .
follow manufacturers recommendations so that pieces are properly interlocked .
c. place tprs perpendicular to traffic and centered in lane .
num .
refer to project details for array placement spacing and signing requirements .
num .
follow manufacturers recommendations and tc series standard drawings for installation and product orientation .
num .
do not glue nail or otherwise affix tprs to the road surface .
d. place tprs at the same time as other traffic control devices prior to work taking place .
num .
maintain the tprs in proper condition alignment spacing and location .
a .
set tprs perpendicular to the travel lane .
num adjust tprs when any one rumble strip becomes skewed by a distance of num ft or more .
skew distance is the distance parallel to direction of travel between the ends of the strip .
implementation num traffic control num page num of num january num num num adjust the tprs if the parallel distance between the individual rumble strips decreases by num ft or more .
num temporary paint marks may be placed to give reference of original locations .
b .
make adjustments to tprs as often as necessary during working hours but at least during each traffic control inspection .
num adjustments to tprs must be made within num minutes of discovery or notification of misalignment .
c. remove tprs during nonworking hours .
e. do not use tprs during snow events or at temperatures outside of the manufacturers recommendations .

num related sections a .
section num geotextiles num references a. aashto m num geotextile specifications for highway applications b. aashto construction stormwater field guide c. astm d num deterioration of geotextiles by exposure to light moisture and heat in a xenon arc type apparatus d. astm d num water permeability of geotextiles by permittivity e. astm d num determining apparent opening size of a geotextile f. utah pollutant discharge elimination system utah construction general permit ucgp num definitions a .
check dam a fiber roll or stone structure placed across a roadside ditch to temporarily protect ditch from channel erosion by slowing velocity of stormwater runoff and intercepting and trapping sediment .
b .
disturbed area areas within a construction site where existing vegetative cover or existing stabilized areas have been removed or altered and exposed soils are susceptible to increased erosion and sedimentation .
implementation num temporary environmental controls num page num of num january num num c. dropinlet barrier a barrier placed around a storm drain inlet grate situated outside of roadway pavement condition that is designed to intercept and trap sedimentladen runoff before entering the storm drain system .
d. fiber roll wood excelsior rice or wheat straw or coconut fibers rolled or bound netting to form a tubelike structure used to intercept and trap sediment .
e. final stabilization procedures and controls completed as the final measure to protect disturbed areas of a construction site from erosion and sedimentation until vegetation regrowth occurs to provide ultimate erosion protection .
num .
includes work within areas to be vegetated such as establishing final grades placing topsoil incorporating seed roughening slopes by walking trackmounted equipment up and down slopes applying mulch erosion control blanket flexible channel liner and installing other landscape treatments to protect exposed soils from erosion .
num .
includes work within areas intended to remain unvegetated such as placing final pavement installing stone gravel and other stable material that will prevent erosion of underlying soil .
f. gutterinlet barrier a device designed and prefabricated to secure to the top envelop or hang below a storm drain inlet grate situated within roadway pavement condition that keeps sediment and debris from entering the storm drain system .
g. pipeinlet barrier a barrier placed at a pipe inlet that intercepts and traps sediment before entering the pipe .
h. sediment trap a small temporary excavated basin installed at low points on a construction site designed to trap sedimentladen runoff to allow sediment to settle out before leaving site .
i. silt fence a geotextile fabric fence used to intercept and trap sediment in a sheet flow situation along the perimeter of a disturbed area .
j. slope drain a polyethylene pipe temporarily placed on a slope to collect and transport storm runoff down the face of a slope until permanent drainage facilities are installed or vegetation growth is adequate .
k. stabilized construction entrance a layer of stone underlined with a geotextile fabric placed at a construction site entrance or exit used to reduce the amount of sediment or mud tracked onto adjacent paved roadways by vehicles leaving the construction site .
implementation num temporary environmental controls num page num of num january num num l. strawbale barrier temporary barrier installed by placing straw bales end to end along perimeter of a disturbed area designed to intercept and slow sediment laden runoff before it leaves a construction site .
m. temporary berm a ridge of compacted soil with or without a shallow ditch that diverts stormwater runoff from a slope to a controlled release point .
n. temporary environmental fence a highvisibility fence barrier used to delineate and prevent encroachment on sensitive areas .

num inspection a .
check installed controls before and after each rain event to verify proper working function and compliance with the ucgp .
b .
replace controls that are not properly working to prevent erosion and sedimentation .
num maintenance a .
maintain controls to function properly until surrounding disturbed areas have met final stabilization measures .
b .
remove accumulated sediments from controls when depth reaches num percent of the control height or when it interferes with the performance of the control .
c. properly dispose of accumulated sediment .
num removal a .
remove temporary environmental controls when surrounding disturbed areas have met final stabilization measures except as follows num .
do not remove perimeter controls such as silt fence fiber rolls or straw bales when they protect a wetland or waterway unless the surrounding area meets final stabilization requirements identified within the ucgp .
num when the engineer determines that controls should remain in place .
b .
remove temporary environmental fence and posts upon completion of construction .

b .
directed surveying .
c. processes and procedures for implementing machine control guidance mcg technology .
mcg uses global positioning system gps and robotic total station rts in conjunction with threedimensional computer models to determine the precise location and elevation of the materials being moved .

develop crosssections from field measurements .
a .

b .
take cross sections at a maximum centerline spacing of numft when the centerline curve radius is less than or equal to num ft. c. take cross sections at a maximum spacing of num ft when the centerline curve radius is greater than num ft. d. take additional cross sections at breaks in terrain and at changes in typical sections .
e. measure and record points at breaks in terrain for each cross section but at least every num ft. f. measure and record points to at least the anticipated slopes and reference locations .
g. reduce cross section distances to horizontal distances from centerline .
h. take cross sections at right angles to tangents and normal to curves .
i .
include in cross sections grades locations and existing ground line profiles .

tolerances stated for each type of construction stake in this table indicates the acceptable deviation of the position of each reference point from its computed position relative to the given alignment and grade .
staked positions are generally checked using electronic stakeout reports and if within tolerances the stated position is accepted .
reference points may also have an accuracy relative to each other for precise measurements such as structures .

the following procedures then apply num .
provide calculations and plots according to section num .
num .

num .

a .
no payments partial or final will be made until submissions are provided and approved .

end of section implementation num rolled erosion control products num page num of num january num num section num rolled erosion control products part num general num section includes a .
rolled erosion control products recp installed on disturbed areas of a construction project including steep slopes and roadside ditches to prevent erosion and sedimentation and assist in establishment of vegetation growth .
num related sections not used num references a. astm d num deterioration of geotextiles by exposure to light moisture and heat in a xenon arc type apparatus b. astm d num tensile properties of geotextiles by the widewidth strip method c. astm d num determination of rolled erosion control product recp performance in protecting hillslopes from rainfallinduced erosion d. astm d num determination of rolled erosion control product recp performance in protecting earthen channels from stormwaterinduced erosion e. astm d num measuring nominal thickness of rolled erosion control products f. astm d num ultimate tensile properties of rolled erosion control products g. astm d num determination of unvegetated rolled erosion control product recp ability to protect sand from hydraulicallyinduced shear stresses under benchscale conditions implementation num rolled erosion control products num page num of num january num num num definitions a .
erosion control blanket ecb temporary recp composed of processed natural or polymer fibers mechanically structurally or chemically bound between two natural fiber or synthetic nettings to form a continuous matrix used to provide erosion control and facilitate vegetation establishment along slopes .
b .
flexible channel liner fcl temporary recp machineproduced mat consisting of elongated natural materials that are bound between two slow degrading natural fiber or synthetic nettings to form a continuous matrix used to reduce erosion and aid vegetation establishment within recently constructed channels ditches and swales .
c. rolled erosion control products recp prefabricated blankets or netting formed from both natural and synthetic materials designed to be installed to a disturbed area and with vegetative growth used to prevent or reduce erosion .
d. turf reinforcement mat trm permanent recp composed of non degradable synthetic fibers filaments nets wire mesh or other elements processed into a permanent threedimensional matrix designed to protect high flow channels ditches and very steep slopes .

manufacturers product data sheets and recommended installation instructions .
num delivery storage and handling a .

num .
protect from damage due to climatic conditions or construction operations .

num .

num .
drive the pile until the required driving resistance is achieved as determined by the dynamic testing and the other pile driving criteria is achieved unless otherwise indicated by the engineer .
refer to this section article num paragraph d. d. the engineer in coordination with the departments geotechnical engineer of record evaluates the driving resistance and driving stresses and establishes driving criteria using a wave equation analysis program with signal matching .
num .
do not complete the driving of other piles in the foundation until the engineer gives notice that the test results indicate that sufficient capacity has been obtained and the driving criteria for the remainder of the piles in the foundation has been established .
e. maximum allowable driving stress is num x pile yield stress fy .
num .

num .
num or more hours after the initial driving of the pile .
num .

g. the department may require the dynamic testing of additional piles and reestablishing driving criteria for the remaining piles within the foundation if pile does not meet the established driving criteria .

c. avoid segregation of the concrete .

num .

implementation num driven piles num page num of num january num num e. use high frequency internal vibrators to consolidate concrete to at least num ft below the bottom of the rebar cage or to at least num ft below the pile cutoff level whichever is deeper .
num .

num .

num .

catch basindrop inlet a structure accepting drainage from gutters or medians or other channels and discharging the water through a conduit .

a structure at the upstream end of a cross culvert .
the upstream end of any structure through which water may flow .

refer to the cb series standard drawings for the standard detail for a manhole .

implementation num concrete drainage structures num page num of num january num num b .
vacuum test follow the test procedure outlined below num .
vacuum test precast structures after assembly and before backfilling .
a .
form a seal between the vacuum base and the manhole rimprecast structure cover .
secure pipe plugs to prevent movement while the vacuum is drawn .
b .
draw a vacuum of num inches of mercury hg .
record the time for the vacuum to drop to num inches .
c. passing drop rates for the time to drop to num inches are diameterwidth time to drop num inch hg up to num ft num seconds num ft and larger num seconds d. make necessary repairs if the structure fails the test .
repairs and repair procedures must be acceptable to the engineer .
e. disassemble the manhole and replace the gaskets if preformed plastic gaskets are pulled out during the vacuum test .
c. exfiltration test follow test procedure astm c num as modified below num .
plug all pipes leading into or out of the precast structure for a watertight seal .
num .
fill precast structure with water to a level num inches below the casting rim or lid .
num .
let the water stand for two hours before beginning the test to allow absorption into the precast structure .
num .
place additional water to bring the water level back to num inches below the rim or lid after the two hour stabilization .
num .
test for at least two hours and verify the leakage is less than shown on table num .

num quality assurance a. precast elements num .
prevent cracking or damage of precast elements during shipping handling and storage .
num .
replace defects and breakage of precast elements .
a .
members that sustain damage or surface defects during fabrication handling storage hauling or erection are subject to review or rejection .
b .
obtain approval before performing repairs .
c. repair work must reestablish the elements structural integrity durability and aesthetics to the satisfaction of the engineer .
d. determine the cause when damage occurs and take corrective action .
e. failure to take corrective action leading to similar repetitive damage can be cause for rejection of the damaged element .
f. cracks that extend to the nearest reinforcement plane and fine surface cracks that do not extend to the nearest reinforcement plane but are numerous or extensive are subject to review and rejection .
g. full depth cracking and breakage greater than num ft are cause for rejection .

implementation num concrete and asphalt cutting num page num of num january num num num procedure asphalt surfaces a .
use any method that provides a vertical cut in a straight line through the full depth of the surface .
num .
saw cut if the method of cutting does not produce a smooth non broken vertical edge .
b .
make cuts so the defective surface can be removed where the edge of the existing surface is cracked broken or deteriorated .
num .
verify that the entire deficient areas are removed and will not propagate .
c. do not allow traffic or construction equipment to cross the cut edge .
d. apply a tack coat to the cut edge before placing hot mix asphalt pavement when appropriate .
refer to section num .

num equipment a .
use mixing equipment specifically designed and manufactured to mix and place microsurfacing .
num .
mix the material by an automatically sequenced selfpropelled microsurfacing mixing machine with a continuous flow revolving multiblade double shafted mixing unit that a .
accurately delivers and proportions the aggregate emulsified asphalt mineral filler controls setting additive and water .
b. discharges the mixed product on a continuous flow basis .
num .
use a machine with sufficient storage capacity for aggregate emulsified asphalt mineral filler control additive and water to maintain an adequate supply to the proportioning controls .
num .
use a machine capable of selfloading materials while continuing to place microsurfacing .
num .
full control of the forward and reverse speed during applications of the microsurfacing material .
a .
use original manufacturer designed equipment for the self loading device opposite side driver stations and forward and reverse speed controls .
b .
use a machine with a hydraulically adjustable while applying mixture type spreader box with a positive screed adjustment for yield control and a positive adjustment for the joint matcher .
implementation num microsurfacing num page num of num january num num c. equip the microsurfacing spreader box with the following num .
ribbon flights mounted on an adjustable shaft to continually agitate and distribute the materials throughout the box .
num .
curb bumpers and replaceable runners with at least num ft long end runners .
num .
a sufficient walkway to provide access to either side of the spreader box without walking through the freshly placed material .
a .
the equipment must provide sufficient turbulence to prevent the mix from setting in the box or causing excessive side buildup or lumps .
num .
flexible seals in contact with the road front and rear to prevent the loss of the mixture from the box .
num .
a secondary strikeoff located approximately num to num ft behind the primary strikeoff to minimize transverse corrugations and to improve surface texture .
a .
the secondary strikeoff must have elevation and width adjustments similar to the primary strikeoff and a pivot point that can be tilted for texturing or raised completely off the surface .
b .
the secondary strikeoff must have the same adjustments as the spreader box .
num .
ability to side shift the box to compensate for variations in the pavement geometry .
num .
capability of applying microsurfacing mixture in variable widths up to num ft. d. use a rut filling spreader box specifically designed to fill ruts with an average depth greater than  inch .
num .
ruts greater than  inch deep require multiple passes to restore the cross section .

num .
calibrate each material control device before each mix application and as often thereafter as determined by the engineer .

num .

part num execution num limitations a .
do not apply microsurfacing during rain when road surface moisture is present or during other adverse weather conditions .
b .
do not apply microsurfacing if either the pavement or air temperature is below num degrees f. c. do not apply microsurfacing when the temperature is projected below num degrees f within num hours of placing microsurfacing .
d. cease microsurfacing operations when the weather or other conditions prolong opening road surface to traffic beyond two hours .
e. remove and replace the microsurfacing if any of the following occurs num .
lumping balling or unmixed aggregates .
num .
separation of the coarse aggregate from the emulsion and fines .
num .
excessive breaking of emulsion inside the spreader box .
num .
streaking caused by oversized aggregate .
num .
flushing or excessively rich areas appearing in the microsurfacing after two hours from the time of placement .
num .
any measurable rutting shoving or other evidence of premature deformation when exposed to traffic .
f. keep traffic off roadway surface until the microsurfacing has cured .
num .
allow for additional curing time at locations such as driveways intersections and where sharp turning movements may take place or where vehicles may accelerate quickly .

c. obtain the engineers written acceptance of a stockpile before its use for microsurfacing .

num .

num preparation a .
clean the pavement surface of dirt sand dust oil and other objectionable material immediately before applying microsurfacing .
b .
allow unsealed cracks to dry thoroughly before applying microsurfacing when using water to clean the road surface .
c. cover manholes valve boxes drop inlets and other service utility entrances before surfacing .
d. protect all structures including items such as guardrail guideposts concrete barriers drains and parapet walls .
num application a. prewet the pavement surface as required due to local conditions by fogging ahead of the microsurfacing box .
num .
do not create standing water on the pavement in front of the micro surfacing box .

implementation num microsurfacing num page num of num january num num b. longitudinal and transverse joints num .
construct longitudinal joints within num inches of the lane lines where possible .
num .
the overlap of microsurfacing at any joint must not exceed num inches .
num .
repair the joints if any of the following conditions exist a .
buildup of material at the joints .
b .
uncovered areas at the joints .
c. longitudinal and transverse joints with more than  inch vertical space between the surface and a num ft straightedge placed perpendicular to the joint .
num .
the edges of the microsurfacing must follow the centerline lane lines shoulder lines and curb lines .
num .
repair the edges if they vary more than num inches .
num .
use methods approved by the engineer to correct deficiencies .
a .
the repaired surfaces must be dense with a uniform texture .
b .
repair sections with surface irregularities the same width as the existing pass of microsurfacing .
c. small areas of patching are not permitted .
c. finished microsurfacing must have a uniform texture free of scratches tears and other surface irregularities .
num .
repair the surface if any of the following deficiencies exist a .
more than one surface irregularity  inch or wider and num ft or longer in any num ft section .
b .
more than three surface irregularities  inch or wider and more than num inches long in any num ft section .
c. any surface irregularity num inch or wider and more than num inches long .
d. any tire track damage to the fresh microsurfacing .
e. slick spots or any area of bleeding surface flushing .
d. place microsurfacing adjacent to concrete pavements or concrete curb and gutter with a straight longitudinal edge .
num .
do not allow overlap in these areas .
e. maintain neat construction lines at all locations .
f. place microsurfacing at side streets and intersections out to rightofway line including around radii where applicable .
implementation num microsurfacing num page num of num january num num g. use hand squeegees to spread microsurfacing in areas where micro surfacing machine can not operate .
num .
lightly dampen areas before mix placement .
num .
provide complete and uniform coverage .
num .
avoid unsightly appearance from handwork .
num .

h. use construction paper or comparable products so that beginning and ending joint lines from each construction pass are straight and neat .

a surface course of one or more layers of hma comprised of aggregate asphalt binder hydrated lime and other additives .
b .
option to incorporate reclaimed asphalt pavement rap materials into hma pavement .
num related sections a .
section num materials dispute resolution b .
section num pavement smoothness c. section nums project specific surfacing requirements d. section num asphalt material e. section num hydrated lime f. section num prime coattack coat num references a. aashto m num superpave volumetric mix design b. aashto r num superpave volumetric design for hotmix asphalt hma c. aashto t num bulk density unit weight and voids in aggregate d. aashto t num determining the liquid limit of soils e. aashto t num determining the plastic limit and plasticity index of soils f. aashto t num resistance to degradation of smallsize coarse aggregate by abrasion and impact in the los angeles machine g. aashto t num soundness of aggregate by use of sodium sulfate or magnesium sulfate implementation num hot mix asphalt hma num num of num january num num h. aashto t num clay lumps and friable particles in aggregate i. aashto t num plastic fines in graded aggregates and soils by use of the sand equivalent test j. aashto t num determining degree of particle coating of asphalt mixtures k. aashto t num theoretical maximum specific gravity and density of hot mix asphalt hma l. aashto t num total evaporable moisture content of aggregate by drying m. aashto t num uncompacted void content of fine aggregate n. aashto t num determining the percentage of fracture in coarse aggregate o. udot materials manual of instruction p. udot minimum sampling and testing requirements q. udot quality management plans num definitions a. longitudinal joint any new asphalt lift abutting an existing paving lift exceeding num feet in length and excluding intersections .
this includes joints created by echelon paving and new asphalt placed against a milled asphalt edge .
b .
lot the number of tons of hma placed in a production day .
c. minor target change a change from the verified mix design gradation target on a maximum of two sieves with the following limitations .
num .
the maximum change in the target gradation on the num or any coarser sieve is limited to num percent passing per sieve .
num .
the maximum change in the target gradation on the num or num sieves is num percent passing per sieve .
num .
the maximum change in the target gradation on the num sieve is num percent passing .
num .
no target change may violate the mix design requirements in this section .
implementation num hot mix asphalt hma num num of num january num num d. overband an num inch protective asphalt coating sealing the longitudinal joint of final riding surface as proposed by the contractor and approved by the engineer e. production day a num hour period in which hma is being placed .
f. rap recycled asphalt pavement .
crushed or milled asphalt materials that have been removed from pavements .
g. thin overlay pavement an overlay where the sum of the thickness of the hma lifts is less than two inches .

density requirements a .
the target for inplace density for the mat is num percent of theoretical maximum specific gravity except for thin overlay pavements .
b .
the target for inplace density for the longitudinal joint is num percent of the theoretical maximum specific gravity gmm .
num use the average of both gmms if two different sides or values exist for the cores taken .
implementation num hot mix asphalt hma num num of num january num num c. the target for inplace density is num percent of theoretical maximum specific gravity for thin overlay pavement projects .
num do not take longitudinal joint cores for thin overlay pavement .

e. acceptance for inplace mat and longitudinal joint density may be based on establishing a rolling pattern for items such as bridge decks utility work traffic signals detours lane leveling driveways other handwork or small projects with plan quantities less than num tons .
num .
thickness requirements are based only on mat cores .
the thickness requirement may be waived when matching up to existing pavement curb and gutter for pavement in or next to intersections .
a .
the department accepts a lot for thickness when num the average thickness is not more than  inch greater or  inch less than the total design thickness specified .
num no individual sublot shows a deficient thickness of more than  inch .
b .
excess thickness the engineer may allow excess thickness to remain in place or may order its removal .
num the department pays for num percent of the mix for material in excess of the  inch tolerance when excess thickness is allowed to remain in place .
c. deficient thickness place additional material where lots or sublots are deficient in thickness .
num the department pays for material necessary to reach specified thickness .
num the department pays for num percent of the mix for additional material over specified thickness necessary to achieve minimum lift thickness .
num minimum compacted lift is num times the nominal maximum aggregate size .
d. thickness tolerances established above do not apply to leveling courses .
check final surfaces in stage construction .
e. check thickness regularly with a depth probe and take corrective action as necessary for thin overlay pavement .

table num definitions abbreviations and formulas for acceptance term explanation target value tv the target values for gradation and asphalt binder content are given in the contractors volumetric mix design .
see this section article num for density target values .
average ave the sum of the lots test results for a measured characteristic divided by the number of test resultsthe arithmetic mean .
sample standard deviations the square root of the value formed by summing the squared difference between the individual test results of a measured characteristic and ave divided by the number of test results minus one .
upper limit ul the value above the tv of each measured characteristic that defines the upper limit of acceptable production .
table num lower limit ll the value below the tv of each measured characteristic that defines the lower limit of acceptable production table num upper quality index qu qu ul aves lower quality index ql ql ave lls percentage of lot within ul pu determined by entering table num with qu .
percentage of lot within ll pl determined by entering table num with ql .
total percentage of lot within ul and ll pt pt pu pl num incentivedisincentive determined by entering table num with pt or pl .
all values for ave s qu and ql will be calculated to at least four decimal places and carried through all further calculations .
rounding to lower accuracy is not allowed .

thickness requirements a .
the department accepts a lot for thickness when num the average thickness is not more than  inch greater or  inch less than the total design thickness specified .
num no individual sublot shows a deficient thickness of more than  inch .
b .
excess thickness the engineer may allow excess thickness to remain in place or may order its removal .
num the department pays for num percent of the mix for material in excess of the  inch tolerance when excess thickness is allowed to remain in place .
num remove and replace the entire depth of the course if it is necessary to remove portions of the course .
c. deficient thickness place additional material where lots or sublots are deficient in thickness .
num the department pays for material necessary to reach specified thickness .
num the department pays for num percent of the mix for additional material over specified thickness necessary to achieve minimum lift thickness .
num minimum compacted lift is num times the nominal maximum aggregate size .
d. thickness tolerances established above do not apply to leveling courses .
num check final surfaces in stage construction .
e. thickness acceptance for thin overlay pavement consists of checking thickness regularly with a depth probe during placement and taking corrective action as necessary .

num num num table num definitions abbreviations and formulas for acceptance term explanation target value tv the target values for gradation and asphalt binder content are given in the contractors mix design .
the target value for density is num percent of maximum rice density .
average ave the sum of the lots test results for a measured characteristic divided by the number of test results the arithmetic mean .
standard deviation s the square root of the value formed by summing the squared difference between the individual test results of a measured characteristic and ave divided by the number of test results minus one .
this statement does not limit the methods of calculations of s other methods that obtain the same value may be used .
upper limit ul the value above the tv of each measured characteristic that defines the upper limit of acceptable production .
table num lower limit ll the value below the tv of each measured characteristic that defines the lower limit of acceptable production table num upper quality index qu qu ul aves lower quality index ql ql ave lls percentage of lot within ul pu determined by entering table num with qu .
percentage of lot within ll pl determined by entering table num with ql .
total percentage of lot pl within ul and ll pt pt pu pl num incentivedisincentive determined by entering table num with pt or pl .
values for ave s qu and ql will be calculated to a minimum two decimal place accuracy that will be carried through all further calculations .
rounding to lower accuracy is not allowed .

num surface placement a .
provide a num horizontal to vertical sloped edge adjacent to the next lane to be paved when fullwidth or echelon paving is impractical and more than one pass is required .
implementation num stone matrix asphalt sma num page num of num january num num b. construct the longitudinal joint to within num inches of the lane lines or at the center of the lane at the direction of the engineer but never in a wheel path .
num .
core and test all longitudinal joints for compaction according to the specification if the lift is num or more inches thick .
num .
verify all edges of the adjacent areas to through lanes have straight and uniform longitudinal lines and neat vertical edges .
num .
fill core holes with sma mix and compact .
c. adjust the production of the mixing plant and material delivery until a steady paver speed is maintained .
d. do not allow construction vehicles general traffic or rollers to pass over the uncompacted end or edge of freshly placed mix until the mat temperature drops to a point where damage or differential compaction will not occur .
e. taper the end of a course subjected to traffic at approximately num horizontal to vertical .
num .
make a transverse joint by saw or wheel cutting and removing the portion of the pass that contains the tapered end .
num .
tack the contact surfaces before fresh mix is placed against the compacted mix .
f. use a material transfer vehicle mtv to apply all courses of sma .
use an mtv that internally performs additional mixing of the sma mix and then deposits material into the paver at a uniform temperature and consistency .
num .
use other approved means to deposit material into the paver when an mtv is impractical placements such as utility work traffic signals detours lane leveling and driveways side street tieins other hand work or small projects with plan quantities less than num tons .
num compaction a .
use a small compactor or vibratory roller in addition to normal rolling at structures .
b .
operate in a transverse direction next to the back wall and approach slab .
c. use a num ton minimum roller .
implementation num stone matrix asphalt sma num page num of num january num num d. roll surface immediately after placement staying as close as possible to the laydown machine and assuring proper mix design placement temperatures .
num .
minimize the use of vibratory rollers .
e. do not use full pneumatic tire rollers .
f. discontinue vibration if aggregate breakdown occurs or if bleeding occurs .
num limitations a .
do not place sma on frozen base or subbase .
b .
use a release agent that does not dissolve asphalt and is satisfactory to the engineer for all equipment and hand tools used to mix haul and place the sma .
c. do not place sma during adverse climatic conditions such as precipitation or when roadway surface is icy or wet .
d. place sma from april num to october num and when the air temperature in the shade and the roadway surface temperature are above num degrees f. num .
the department determines if it is feasible to place sma outside these dates and temperature .
num .
obtain authorization from the engineer before paving outside these limits .

b .
compliance limit the limit for acceptance without price reductions accounting for testing variability for the listed properties .
c. composite price reduction the sum of price reductions for all individual properties associated with a single asphalt binder sample .
d. rejection limit the limit for acceptance with price reductions .
material not meeting these limits will be rejected and removed and replaced .

implementation num asphalt material num page num of num january num num num .
material not meeting the compliance limit but within the rejection limit the price reduction applied to the mix pay item price is calculated as follows num .
the composite price reduction will be calculated by summing the price reduction for each parameter if more than one parameter lies outside specification limits .
a .
the mix material will be rejected if the composite price reduction exceeds num .
b .
the maximum composite price reduction from the tested samples is applied to the mix in the binder lot if multiple samples from the binder lot are tested .
c. adjacent samples in the preceding current or subsequent lots may be tested to assess the extent and limit the amount of mix to be rejected if a binder lot is rejected .

num .

num .

a .

b .

implementation num portland cement concrete pavement num page num of num january num num c. maintain misters at least num ft above the concrete surface and aimed in a direction above horizontal .
d. do not use fogging to apply excess water to the concrete surface to aid finishing .
e. do not affect the watercement ratio of the concrete .
f. discontinue fogging when a fine coating of water or sheen is visible on the concrete surface .

c. remove and replace panels when multiple full depth cracks separate the panel into three or more pieces .
d. use methods that do not disturb or damage adjacent panels .
e. remove and replace panel with any full depth transverse crack within num ft or less of a transverse sawed joint .

num .

refer to section num .
i .

num limitations general a .
meet limitations of section num except as modified below .
b .
night operations num .
provide proper lighting from  hour after sunset to  hour before sunrise according to section num .
c. precipitation num .
cease operation when rain is threatening .
num .
remove replace or repair any pavement damaged by rain or hail as determined by the engineer .
a. pavement is considered damaged when rain or hail leaves noticeable texture on the surface .
b .
do not finish rainwater or hail into the concrete surface .
d. surface evaporation num .
limitations apply at any time of the year when any combination of air temperature relative humidity and wind velocity have the potential to impair the quality of fresh or hardened concrete or otherwise result in abnormal properties .
num .
prepare materials required for evaporation control measures and have them available on site .
implementation num portland cement concrete pavement num page num of num january num num num .
initiate evaporation control measures when concrete and air temperatures relative humidity of the air and wind velocity have the capacity to evaporate water from a free water surface at a rate equal to or greater than num lbftnumhr .
a .
determine the evaporation rate of surface moisture by the menzel formula .
refer to aci num .
e. mix consistency num .
cease operations when three consecutive paving sublots warrant acceptance at a reduced rate due to compressive strength .
num .
cease operations upon having four consecutive batches rejected due to noncompliant air content of the mix .
num .
do not resume paving operations until the issues have been resolved to the satisfaction of the engineer .
a .
delays due to ceased operations are not excusable .
num limitations cold weather a .
cold weather limitations apply when the temperature is forecast to fall below num degrees f within num calendar days of placement .
b .
comply with the following requirements for placing concrete in cold weather num .
do not use chemical additives in the concrete to prevent freezing .
num .
provide all necessary cold weather protection for inplace concrete using items such as covers insulation and heat .
num .
do not place concrete in contact with frozen surfaces .
num .
adequately vent combustiontype heaters that produce carbon monoxide .
num .
protect the concrete from freezing when the ambient air temperature is num degrees f or below until a compressive strength of num psi has been achieved determined by either a .
maturity method aashto t num b .
field cure cylinders num .
maintain moist conditions for exposed concrete to avoid loss of moisture from the concrete due to heat applied .
num .
limit the drop in temperature next to the concrete surfaces when removing heat to num degrees f during any num hour period until the surface temperature of the concrete reaches that of the atmosphere .
num .
measure monitor and record the concrete surface temperature at the frequency in the approved cold weather protection plan .
a .
provide the data to the department within num hours of measurement .
num .
paving may begin when base surface temperature is num degrees f in the shade and rising .
implementation num portland cement concrete pavement num page num of num january num num num .
cease operations when the ambient temperature is num degrees f in the shade and decreasing .
num .
remove and replace concrete when any portion of the panel has frozen .
num .
do not use material containing frost or lumps .
c. heating aggregate and water num .
provide and operate heating devices when heated aggregates are required .
num .
use aggregates free of ice .
num .
heat aggregates uniformly avoid overheating or developing hot spots .
num .
use either steam or dry heat .
num limitations hot weather a .
comply with approved hot weather protection plan when ambient air temperature is num degrees f to num degrees f in the shade .
b .
discontinue paving when ambient air temperature exceeds num degrees f in the shade .

num equipment a .
use distributor trucks according to the following requirements num .
tachometer pressure gauges accurate volume measuring devices or a calibrated tank and a thermometer for measuring temperatures of the tank contents .
num .
insulated tanks capable of storing the binder at temperatures that allow the binder to remain consistent with the appropriate viscosity for proper application rates .
a .
use tanks equipped with baffles to prevent pressure surges resulting from the asphalt sloshing in the tank when starting and stopping .
b .
use trucks equipped with devices to provide for accurate and rapid correlation and control of the amount of bituminous material being applied with that of the truck or distributor gauges .
num .
constant volume circulation pumps and heaters to maintain a pressurized system so binder will be uniformly heated .
a .
circulation pump must spray a constant volume for the entire length of the spray bar for each application .
num .
spray bar and nozzles designed to provide an appropriate fan width to provide uniform transverse distribution without corrugation or streaking .
a .
adjust the spray bar height to provide uniform distribution of binder across the application width and triple lapping of the binder on the pavement surface .
b .
use a fully circulating spray bar with a positive shutoff valve .

num hydrostatic system capable of maintaining a tolerance of num galydnum .

b .
use a selfpropelled aggregate chip spreader specifically designed and manufactured for chip seal operations equipped with the following num .
computerized controls that will apply a uniform even layer of aggregate across the full width of the binder and adjust output to the unit ground speed .
a .
use gates adjustable to drop the correct amount of aggregate plus or minus num lbydnum .
num .
variable width spreader with hydraulic control extension and adjustable discharge gates .
num .
spreading hopper with a minimum capacity to cover a full lane of travel plus num ftpass .
num .
spinner broadcast type of aggregate spreader not allowed .
c. use sufficient number of dump trucks to circumvent any interruption in the supply of chips to the spreader .
num .
use tandem axle dump trucks or larger or conveyor discharge trucks to minimize the number of hookups .
num .
use dump trucks with matching hitches and compatible with the aggregate spreader to provide smooth hookups and to minimize any spillage when loading the hopper .
num .
use trucks in good mechanical condition and that do not leak .
a .
use truck tires that do not pick up binder or aggregate when driving on the new surface .
d. use at least three articulating type pneumatic rollers for rolling operations .
num .

use rollers with pneumatic tires of equal size diameter and having treads satisfactory to the engineer .
num .
inflate tires so that the entire roller width area is compacted by either the rearaxle tires or the frontaxle tires .
a. inflate tires to num lbinnum or lower as approved by the engineer .
num maintain tire pressure within num lbinnum .

num .

num .

num .

b .

num .
a lot is evaluated on the test results of four samples with the following exceptions a. compute incentivedisincentive using the test results from three samples if only three samples can be taken for the production day .
b .
add the lot to the next days production if three random samples can not be taken .
c. add the lot to the previous days production for the last days production if three random samples can not be taken .
d. the lot may be increased to include up to three production days when approved in advance by the engineer and when less than num tons are anticipated per production day .

average ave the sum of the lots test results for a measured characteristic divided by the number of test results the arithmetic mean .
sample standard deviations the square root of the value formed by summing the squared difference between the individual test results of a measured characteristic and ave divided by the number of test results minus one .
upper limit ul the value above the tv of each measured characteristic that defines the upper limit of acceptable production .
table num lower limit ll the value below the tv of each measured characteristic that defines the lower limit of acceptable production .

rounding to lower accuracy is not allowed .

course bwc num num of num january num num z. udot quality management plans num definitions a. bonded wearing course bwc a spraypaver applied surface treatment consisting of a warm polymermodified emulsion membrane and an ultrathin gapgraded hot mix asphalt overlay .
it is typically less than num inch thick .
the hot mix asphalt surface course is placed immediately on the emulsion .
a bwc is a homogeneous wearing surface and pavement seal that can be opened to traffic immediately after cooling .
b. polymermodified emulsion membrane pmem a warm modified emulsion applied to the pavement to seal the underlying pavement and provide a strong bond to the surface course .
c. production day a num hour period in which bwc is being placed .

num .

a .
make no contact between the wheel or other part of the paving machine and the pmem before applying the hot mix asphalt .
b .

num additives a .
use additives as required to accelerate or retard the breakset of the slurry seal or to improve the resulting finished surface .
num .
determine the initial additive quantities by the mix design for the slurry mix or individual materials .
num .
obtain engineer approval .
num slurry seal mix design a .
use a department approved laboratory conforming to the issa anum tested listed in table num .
num .
use the same materials and aggregate gradation to be used on the project .
table num tests issa test no .
description specification issa tb num slurry seal consistency numcm minimum numcm maximum issa tbnum for quicktraffic systems wet cohesion num minutes minimum set wet cohesion num minutes minimum num kgcm minimum num kgcm minimum issa tb num for heavytraffic areas only excess asphalt by lwt sand abrasion num gftnum maximum num gmnum maximum issa tbnum wet stripping pass num minimum issa tbnum wettrack abrasion loss onehour soak num gftnum num gmnum issa tbnum mix time controllable to num seconds minimum perform the mixing test and settime test at the highest temperatures expected during construction .
implementation num asphalt slurry seal coat num page num of num january num num num equipment a .
use only a machine designed and manufactured specifically for blending mixing and placing slurry seal .
num .
mix the material in a selfpropelled slurry seal mixing machine of either truckmounted or continuousrun design .
a continuousrun machines equipped to selfload materials while continuing to lay slurry seal .
b either type machine accurately deliver and proportion the aggregate emulsified asphalt mineral filler control setting additive and water to a revolving mixer and to discharge the mixed product on a continuousflow basis .
num .
maintain sufficient storage capacity within the machine for aggregate emulsified asphalt mineral filler control additive and water to maintain an adequate supply to the proportioning controls .
b. calibrate each mixing unit in the presence of the engineer before a machine is used on a project part num execution num limitations a .
do not apply slurry seal during rain when road surface moisture is present or during other adverse weather conditions .
b .
do not apply slurry seal if either the pavement or air temperature is below num degrees f and falling .
num .
slurry seal may be applied when both the pavement and air temperatures are above num degrees f and rising .
c. do not apply slurry seal when the temperature is projected below num degrees f within num hours of placing slurry seal .
d. cease slurry seal operations when weather or other conditions prolong opening road surface to traffic beyond two hours .
e. keep traffic off roadway surface until the slurry seal has cured .
num stockpile a. construct individual numton stockpiles of slurry seal aggregates .
num .
engineer approves stockpiles at least one and at most seven days before use .
implementation num asphalt slurry seal coat num page num of num january num num b .
notify the engineer at least seven calendar days before slurry seal placement in order for the initial stockpiles to be sampled and tested for acceptance .
c. obtain the engineers written acceptance of all stockpiles before use in slurry seal .
d. remove material not meeting specifications from the stockpile area .
e. the department will retest corrected material for acceptance .
num preparation a .
clean the surface of all dirt sand dust oil and other objectionable material immediately before applying the slurry .
b .
allow cracks to dry thoroughly before applying slurry seal when using water to clean the surface .
c. protect manholes valve boxes drop inlets and other service utility entrances before surfacing .
num application a. prewet the entire surface by fogging ahead of the slurry box .
num .
do not over apply causing free water to sit on the pavement in front of the slurry box .
b .
carry a sufficient amount of slurry in all parts of the spreader at all times so that full width and complete coverage is obtained with no streaks or narrow spots .
num .
avoid overloading the spreader .
c. apply slurry mixture of proper consistency at an average rate of num to num lbydnum of dry aggregate .
d. do not add additional water for any reason once the mixture has been placed onto the road surface .
e. remove and replace the slurry if any of the following occurs num .
lumping balling or unmixed aggregates .
num .
separation of the coarse aggregate from the emulsion and fines .
num .
settling of the coarse aggregate to the bottom of the mix .
num .
excessive breaking of emulsion inside the spreader box .
num .
streaking caused by oversized aggregate .
implementation num asphalt slurry seal coat num page num of num january num num num finishing details a .
do not create buildup when constructing longitudinal and transverse joints .
b .
place slurry seal adjacent to concrete pavements or concrete curb and gutter with a straight longitudinal edge .
num .
do not allow overlap on these areas .
num .
remove slurry seal placed on concrete .
c. maintain straight lines at all locations .
d. place slurry seal at side streets and intersections out to rightofway line .
e. use hand squeegees to spread slurry in areas that can not be reached with slurry seal machine .
num .
lightly dampen areas before mix placement .
num .
provide complete and uniform coverage .
num .
avoid unsightly appearance from hand work .
num .
use the same type of finish in hand worked areas as applied by the spreader box .
f. use construction paper or comparable products so all beginning and ending joint lines from each construction pass are straight .

combination wildlife escape ramp three earthen ramps two opposite each other and perpendicular to the rightofway fence plus one between them parallel perpendicular to the rightofway fence creating a three sided corral for animals to jump into to escape from the rightofway .

refer to fg series standard drawings .

implementation num wbeam guardrail num page num of num january num num num raising existing wbeam guardrail a .
raise wbeam guardrail to maintain the minimum rail height according to ba series standard drawings .
num .
only wbeam guardrail with two or threehole post system is eligible to be raised .
a .
raise the two or threehole post systems rail element only if the rail element is not currently set in the highest hole .
num .
wbeam guardrail with singlehole post system can not be raised .
do not lift posts in order to raise rail .
b .
remove existing rail element and blocks .
c. complete shoulder grading as required by ba series standard drawings .
d. reinstall rail elements and blocks on existing two or threehole post system using the next hole up on the two or threehole system to meet the height requirements according to ba series standard drawings .
num .
do not drill new holes in posts .

num quality control flexible post testing a .
meet cold bend test num .
subject two posts to a temperature of num degrees f num degrees f for at least four hours .
num .
immediately bend each post four times through a num degree angle around a num inch mandrel .
num .
each post must return to its original straight configuration within a num degree angle within five minutes at the end of the four bends .
num .
any cracking or significant loss of rigidity are grounds for failure .
b .
meet hot bend test num .
subject two posts to a temperature of num degrees f num degrees f for at least four hours .
num .
satisfy all bending and physical requirements specified in the cold bend test .
c. meet impact resistance test num .
subject post to impacts by a typical sedan as follows a .
three hits num degree angle at num degrees f. b .
three hits num degree angle at num degrees f. c. ten hits num degree angle at num mph .
d. five hits num degree angle at num mph .

acceptable results a .
installed post remain intact securely anchored and within num degrees of vertical orientation .
b .
installed post shows minimal signs of cracking or loss of rigidity .
c. installed post retains at least num percent of its reflective sheeting .
d. impact vehicle suffers little or no damage during the impact test .
d. exposure num .
expose the specimens for num hours in a carbon arctype apparatus according to astm g num method num .
num .
acceptable results a .
exposure does not result in delamination distress or discoloration .
b. sheeting is not removable from the specimens without damage .
c. post is resistant to ultraviolet light ozone hydrocarbons and other weathering .

num concrete foundations requirements a .
line posts num .
castinplace post foundation a .
do not over excavate hole .
b .
install manufactures required reinforcing steel .
c. install post sleeve no greater than  inch above finished grade of foundation .
d. fill the excavated hole with concrete .
dome concrete down from top of post sleeve to flush with finished grade .
refer to ba num series standard drawings .
num do not use a tubular concrete form for foundation casting .
num post sleeve will be within  inch alignment to the post on either side .
a sleeve alignment can be adjusted to meet placement requirements on a horizontal curve .
b meet manufacturers requirements if supplied system uses offset posts .
num install foundation in such a manner that the post will stand vertically and be no greater than  inch from plumb .
e. allow concrete to cure a minimum of seven days and achieve num psi before installing cable .
b. castinplace nonnchrp num cable barrier anchor deadman anchor num .
install according to manufacturers specification .
a. excavate hole and form a castinplace anchor .
num install reinforcing steel according to cable manufacturers requirements .
num install hardware according to cable manufacturers requirements for cable attachment .
num install so the top of the anchor block will be at the same grade and elevation as the three consecutive posts foundations approaching the anchor block .
implementation num high tension cable barrier num page num of num january num num b .
place concrete and allow to cure a minimum of seven days or achieve num psi before connecting and tensioning cable .
c. backfill with excavated material .
compact material around the castinplace anchor block to a minimum of num percent of maximum laboratory density .
refer to section num .
dispose of excess material by removal or grade into surrounding area .
num install so that anchor block will not move greater than num inches toward the opposite cable anchor or terminal during tensioning or after tensioning has been completed .
remove and replace with a larger block or secure so that no additional decrease of cable tension occurs if anchor block moves greater than num inches .

implementation num precast retainingnoise walls num page num of num january num num num .

a manufacturers recommended liquidrelease agent that will not bond with stain or adversely affect precast concrete surfaces and will not impair subsequent surface or joint treatments of precast concrete .
b .
a nonpetroleum release agent meeting all epa requirements .
c. a release agent that is not detrimental to concrete strength or durability and that does not impart color tint or texture to the finished product .

num .

num related sections not used num references a. astm b num aluminum and aluminumalloy sheet and plate b. astm d num retroreflective sheeting for traffic control c. code of federal regulations cfr d. construction of roads and bridges on federal highway projects fpnum num definitions a. retroreflective sheeting num .
sheeting the retroreflective or nonreflective material that comprises the background legend word messages and symbols and border .
num .
sheeting components the matched component products required for the manufacture of highway signs consist of the sheeting cutout letters and borders adhesives inks and overlay films .
failure of the sheeting inks or overlay films provided sold or recommended for use constitute a failure of the entire sign and replacement under manufacturers warranty replacement obligations .
all components and warranties will be compatible with substrates used by the department including aluminum astm b num num h num or numtnum .
num .
permanent signs include sign installations that are in their final configuration and that are expected to have a multiyear life .
examples include freeway guide signs regulatory signs warning signs barrier markers crash cushion markers and delineation .
implementation num retroreflective sheeting num page num of num january num num num .
work zone standard signs mutcd and department standard application signs including but not limited to road work ahead work zone speed limit flagger symbols business access and regulatory signing within the work zone .
num .
work zone project specific signs signs that have legends specific to the project and that can not be reused on a future project .
examples include alder street closed from numst to numnd avenue use birch street or project notification signs .
these are typically used for only one construction season .
num .
flexible work zone devices include such devices as roll up signs cones tall cones and flags with retroreflective sheeting .
num .
work zone channelization devices include such devices as drums vertical panels barricades tubular markers and pavement marking tabs .

num .

udot steel and concrete construction manual num definitions a. snug tight the tightness that is attained with a few impacts of an impact wrench or the full effort of an ironworker using an ordinary spud wrench to bring the plies into firm contact .

onetime repair by welding of deficient weld is allowed without written authorization from the engineer .
num .
longitudinal seam welds a .
use fullpenetration groove welds for post and mast arm sections .
b .
for full span type structures locate the seam weld for the mast arm in the lower quadrant of the mast arm compression side under dead load .
c. for cantilever type structures locate the seam weld for the mast arm in the upper quadrant of the mast arm compression side under dead load .
d. for posts locate the seam weld on the same side as the mast arm compression side under dead load .

num tackifier a .
general num .
free from growth or germination inhibiting factors .
num .
nonflammable num .
nontoxic to aquatic organisms .
num .
functional for a minimum of num days .
b. guarbased tackifier num .
derived from ground endosperm of guar seeds cyamopsis tetragonolobus and treated with dispersant agents .
num .
apply at a rate of num lbs per acre .
c. psylliumbased tackifier num .
manufactured from the finely ground muciloid coating of plantago ovata or plantago ispaghula seeds .
num .
will hydrate when mixed with water to form a slurry and produces a firm resilient and rewettable membrane on the soil surface after application .
num .
apply at a rate of num lb per acre .
d. starchbased tackifier num .
typically derived from corn or potatoes in a nonionic coldwater soluble pregelatinized granular form .
num .
apply at a rate of num lbacre .

implementation num seed turf seed and turf sod num page num of num january num num num seeding general a .
notify the engineer seven working days before seeding .
b .

note that drill seed and broadcast seed are applied at different rates .
num drill seeding method a .
use the drill method of seeding on accessible slopes num and flatter .
b .
use a drill equipped with the following num .
depth band num .
seed box agitator num .
seed metering device num .
furrow opener num .
packer wheels or drag chains c. use the drill manufacturers directions in the presence of the engineer .
calibrate the drill to apply seed at the rate indicated in the seeding schedule .
d. space drill rows a minimum of num inches and a maximum of num inches .
e. fill the seed boxes no more than half full when drilling on a slope .
f. set depth bands to drill seeds to a  inch depth .
g. drill along the contour .
h. maintain the drill at the calibrated setting throughout the seeding operation .
i .
allow the furrows that are created by the drill to remain .
num broadcast seeding method a .
use the broadcast method of seeding under the following conditions num .
slopes steeper than num .
num .
slopes num and flatter where the area to be seeded is inaccessible to drill .
num .
the area to be seeded is not large enough to justify using a drill .
num .
rocky surface conditions will damage a drill .
implementation num seed turf seed and turf sod num page num of num january num num b .
obtain approval of the broadcast method by demonstrating the procedure on a num ydnum area .
c. evenly broadcast seed using either num .
a cyclone seeder or other approved mechanical seeder .
num .
a hydroseeder .
a apply seed water and num lb of cellulose fiber mulch tracer per acre .
d. do not seed during windy weather or when soil is saturated .
e. incorporate the seed into the soil by one of three methods num .
cattracking by running the dozer up and down the slope creating continuous cleat tracks that run parallel with the contours .
num .
hand raking the seed in  inch deep and along the contours of the slope .
num .
slope chaining by pulling the chain along the contour until the seed is covered .
f. obtain approval from the engineer that the seed has been adequately incorporated into the soil before applying wood fiber mulch erosion control blanket flexible growth medium flexible channel liner or other topdressing .
num turf seeding a .
apply turf seed after seedbed preparation .
refer to this section article num paragraph c. b .
roll seeded areas using a hand roller half filled with water .
c. lightly water and program the irrigation system to maintain a moist seedbed .
d. rope off newly seeded areas along walkways using bright plastic ribbon tape attached to stakes .
num turf sod placement a .
prepare sod bed and place sod with all edges and joints tightly butted .
num .
do not stretch or overlap sod .
num .
keep length seams in a straight line .
b .
lay turf sod with staggered joints and trim off excess material along the edges .
implementation num seed turf seed and turf sod num page num of num january num num c. roll sod immediately after placing using a hand roller half filled with water .
num .
reroll if depressions still remain .
num .
thoroughly water with a fine spray to a depth sufficient that the underside of the new sod and soil immediately below the sod are thoroughly wet .

b .

c. remove num inch from the basal end of the pole or cutting just before planting .
d. place one pole or one cutting in the hole basal end first .
e. backfill and compact around the pole or cutting to eliminate air pockets .
f. water the pole or cutting and add more backfill if settling occurs .

b .

h. do not remove branches that will deform the appearance of the tree .

within num minutes of batching when the air temperature is above num degrees f. b .
