cold weather applies when the temperature is forecast to fall below num degrees f during the protection period .
num .
provide necessary cold weather protection for placing finishing curing and protecting inplace concrete such as covers insulation and heat .
a .
follow the authorized cold weather concreting plan when placing castinplace concrete .
b .
follow the prequalified suppliers approved quality control plan when fabricating precast concrete members .
num .
concrete materials a .
do not use chemical antifreeze additives in the concrete .
this does not apply to normal accelerators .
refer to aashto m num. b .
remove and replace concrete damaged by frost action at no additional cost to the department .
c. do not use material containing frost or lumps .
num .
determine the concrete compressive strength by one of the following methods a .
field cured cylinders cured and protected the same as the concrete being protected .
b .
maturity method .
refer to aashto t num .
num .
maintain the temperature of the concrete at or above num degrees f during and after placement until the end of the protection period .
a .
measure the specified concrete temperature at the concrete surface .
use surface thermometers insulated from the surrounding air .
num .
placing concrete a .
do not place concrete during adverse weather including rain snow and high winds without adequate protection approved by the engineer .
b .
do not proceed with the placement of concrete if the temperature of all contact surfaces including reinforcement is less than num degrees f or greater than num degrees f. c. cease placement operations when the ambient temperature is num degrees f and decreasing unless adequate precautions are taken according to the approved cold weather concreting plan .
num .
protection of inplace concrete a .
maintain the concrete above num degrees f during placement and until the end of the protection period .
num the protection period is the time required for the concrete to reach a compressive strength of at least num psi .
implementation num portland cement concrete num page num of num january num num num extend the duration of the protection period at least num hr beyond the termination of the cure before exposing the concrete to freezing temperatures when curing by the water method .
refer to section num. b .
comply with the following when heating is required .
num adequately vent combustiontype heaters that produce carbon monoxide .
num position heaters and ducts so the hot dry air does not cause areas of the concrete surface to overheat or dry .
num keep concrete surfaces moist to avoid excessive loss of moisture from the concrete when applying external heat .
num .
termination of protection a .
limit the drop in temperature of concrete surfaces to num degrees f during any num hour period when removing cold weather protection until the surface temperature of the concrete reaches that of the ambient air temperature .
e. hot weather comply with the following when placing finishing curing and protecting concrete exposed to hot weather during the protection period .
num .
hot weather limitations apply at any time of the year when a combination of high ambient temperature high concrete temperature low relative humidity and high wind speed have the potential to impair the quality of freshly mixed or hardened concrete by accelerating the rate of moisture loss and the rate of cement hydration or otherwise causes detrimental results .
num .
monitor site conditions including air temperature relative humidity and wind speed to assess the need for evaporation control measures .
a .
begin monitoring no later than num hour before beginning concrete placing operations .
b .
continue to monitor site conditions at intervals of num minutes or less until required curing procedures are applied .
num .
provide necessary hot weather protection .
a .
follow the approved hot weather concreting plan when placing castinplace concrete .
b .
follow the prequalified suppliers approved quality control plan when fabricating precast concrete members .
implementation num portland cement concrete num page num of num january num num c. initiate evaporation control measures when concrete and air temperatures relative humidity of the air and wind speed have the capacity to evaporate free water from the fresh concrete surface at a rate equal to or greater than num lbftnumhr .
num determine the evaporation rate of surface moisture using the nrmca nomograph in appendix b of aci num .
num .

provide and maintain cylinder storage device .
num .
maintain cylinders at a temperature range of num degrees f to num degrees f for the initial num hour curing period .
num .
do not move the cylinders during this period .
num .
equip the storage device with an automatic num hour temperature recorder that continuously records on a timetemperature chart with an accuracy of num degree f. num .
have the storage device available at the point of placement at least num hours before placement .
num .
stop placement of concrete if the storage device is not provided or can not accommodate the required number of test cylinders .
cylinder strength results may not be disputed if storage devices are not provided .
num .
use water containing hydrated lime if water is to be in contact with cylinders .
num .
the engineer may require a num hour test run to determine the storage device capability to maintain and record temperature .

implementation num reinforcing steel and welded wire num page num of num january num num num connection procedure using grouted splice couplers a .
use personnel familiar with installation and grouting of splice couplers and that have completed at least two successful projects in the last two years .
num .
train new personnel within three months of installation by a manufacturers technical representative as an acceptable substitution for the experience .
b remove and clean all debris from the joints before grout application .
c. keep bonding surfaces free from laitance dirt dust paint grease oil or any contaminants other than water .
d. embed rebar anchor dowels to the minimum coupler embedment required by the manufacturer .
e. saturate surface dry ssd all joint surfaces before connecting the elements .
f. use shims to verify that the reinforcing extensions are within the manufacturers recommended tolerance .
g. maintain a minimum grout and sleeve temperature of num degrees f. monitor the temperature of the covered grouted slice couplers until the temporary bracing is removed .
h. conform to the manufacturers instructions for grout mixing water to grout ratio mixing time and shelf life .
i .
mix structural grout and coupler grout just before use according to the manufacturers instructions .
j .
follow the manufacturers recommendations for coupler installation and grouting .
k. monitor the grouting operation to verify that all sleeves have been filled .
l. verify that all sleeves are protected from any vibration shock or other excessive movement until temporary bracing is removed .
m. conform to the following when installing couplers above a horizontal joint num .
determine the thickness of shims to provide the specified elevation within tolerance .
num .
follow nonshrink grout manufacturers recommendations for mixing joint surface preparation and application .
implementation num reinforcing steel and welded wire num page num of num january num num num .
place nonshrink grout on the interface between the two elements being joined before setting the element .
a .
crown the thickness of the grout toward the center of the joint so that the grout can be displaced outward as the element is lowered onto the joint .
b .
prevent the grout from entering the coupler above elements by using grout dams or seals .
num .
set the element in place .
a .
engage all couplers in the joint .
b .
allow the grout to seep out of the joint .
num .
trowel off excess grout to form a neat joint once the element is set plumbed and aligned .
a .
pack grout into any voids around the joint perimeter .
num .
flush out the coupler with clean potable water .
num .
mix the special coupler grout according to the manufacturers recommendations for methods and proportions of mix and water .

b .

c. place the coupler grout into the coupler by pouring or pumping .

treated opaque x. pti mnum posttensioning institute pti guide specification for grouted posttensioning implementation num posttensioning concrete num page num of num january num num y. pti mnum posttensioning institute pti specification for grouting of posttensioned structures num definitions a. inlet and outlet pipes the terms inlet pipes and outlet pipes are synonymous with vents drains injection ejection or inletoutlet ports .
inlet and outlet pipes are devices connected to the pt system used for the injection of materials into or the ejection of materials from inside the ducts .
b. jacking force the force applied to the tendon before anchorage and the occurrence of losses including the anchor set loss .
c. permanent force the force remaining in the prestressing steel after all losses including long term creep and shrinkage of concrete elastic shortening of concrete relaxation of steel losses in prestressing steel due to sequence of stressing friction unintended wobble of ducts anchor set friction in anchorages and all other losses particular to the method or system of prestressing have taken place or have been provided for .
d. torpedo a rigid object sized to fit through undamaged posttensioning ducts .
used to prove that installed ducts have not been blocked or damaged during the concrete pour .
num submittals a .
working drawings num .
detailed drawings of the pt system for review .
include at least the following a. anchorage and bearing details including local zone and grillage reinforcement b. duct placement including individual tendon center of gravity cg locations and combined tendon cg location at anchorages low points and high points num not required for segmental bridges or precast deck panels num distribute the prestressing force in castinplace post tensioned bridge girders with approximately equal quantity in each girder and place the force symmetrically about the centerline of the structure c. method and spacing of duct supports d. duct ties and stirrup ties e. inlet and outlet pipe locations f. expected friction coefficient wobble coefficient and anchor set g. jacking forces jacking ends initial stresses and sequence implementation num posttensioning concrete num page num of num january num num h. permanent grout cap detail i .

c. use bar couplers only at the locations shown .
num .
use mechanical couplers that develop at least num percent of the actual ultimate strength of the bar tested in an unbonded state without exceeding anticipated set .
num .

d. protect prestressing steel against physical damage and rust or other results of corrosion at all times from manufacture to grouting or encasing in concrete .
num .
do not use prestressing steel that has sustained physical damage .
num .
remove and discard lengths of strand containing broken wire .
num .
use wire that is bright and uniformly colored having no foreign matter or pitting on its surface .
num .
package prestressing steel in containers or shipping forms to protect the steel against physical damage and corrosion during shipping and storage .
a .
use a corrosion inhibitor which prevents rust or other results of corrosion placed in the package or form num use a corrosion inhibitor either placed in the package form or applied directly to the steel that has no deleterious effect on the steel grout concrete or bond strength of steel to grout .
num use inhibitor carrier type packaging material that conforms to the provisions of federal specification milprfnum .

num posttensioning anchorages a .
use anchoring devices that develop at least num percent of the actual ultimate tensile strength of the prestressing steel tested in an unbonded state without exceeding the anticipated set .
num ducts a .
general num .
use corrugated galvanized metal ducts corrugated plastic ducts rigid steel pipe ducts or smooth plastic ducts .
a .
use ducts that are mortar tight and capable of withstanding concrete pressures without deforming or permitting the entrance of cement paste during the placing of concrete .
b .
use ducts that can be accurately bent and placed at the locations shown .
num .
minimum internal dimensions for a. multistrand tendons crosssectional area num times the crosssectional area of the prestressing steel b. prestressing bars diameter  inches larger than bar outside diameter measured across deformations c. prestressing bars with couplers diameter  inches larger than largest dimension of the largest enclosed element num enclose bar couplers and coupler components in housings long enough to permit the necessary movements num .
use ducts that have properties compatible with the assumed design values shown .
num .
use ducts that can be bent as shown without crimping or flattening and have sufficient strength to maintain their correct alignment during placing of concrete .
num .
use duct splices at joints between precast segments that are capable of positively preventing the entrance of cement paste and water from concrete .
a .
use duct splices that do not cause electrolytic action or deteriorate .
implementation num posttensioning concrete num page num of num january num num num .
provide reference marks on rigid ducts to facilitate orientation during placement .
num .
provide hold down ties to the forms when the buoyancy of the ducts in the fluid concrete would lift the reinforcing steel .
b .
metal ducts num .

num tendon installation a. verify that ducts are unobstructed undamaged and free of water and debris after completion of concrete placement and before installing the prestressing steel .
num .
prove that the ducts are clear of obstructions or damage by passing a suitably sized torpedo through the ducts .
a .
size the torpedo  inch smaller than the clear inside dimensions of the duct with rounded ends .
b .
use a num ft long torpedo for straight ducts .
c. size the torpedo for sharply curved ducts such that when both ends touch the outermost wall the torpedo is at least  inch clear of the inside wall .
d. the member will be rejected if the torpedo will not easily travel completely through the duct .
e. using a torpedo to verify that ducts are clear is not required for four strand tendons in flat ducts used for transverse pt of segmental boxgirders placed before concrete casting .
num prove pt ducts are free and clear of obstructions or damage by moving the group of strands back and forth in duct for a minimum distance of num ft in each direction .
num move strands easily by hand without resorting to excessive effort or mechanical assistance .
num .
flush ducts with oilfree and waterfree compressed air or water as required to remove unwanted material from inside of ducts .
a. ducts subjected to contamination with chlorides water used for flushing ducts may contain slack lime calcium hydroxide or quicklime calcium oxide in the amount of num lbgal .
num test for presence of chlorides and oils in discharged water before placing tendons .
num continue to flush if chloride levels in flush water outflow exceeded num ppm until chloride level in flush water outflow is below num ppm .
implementation num posttensioning concrete num page num of num january num num b .
blow all water out of the duct with oilfree compressed air and swab dry after flushing .
b .
conduct duct pressure field tests before installing the internal or external prestressing steel .
num .
install grout caps inlet and outlet port caps and other components necessary to seal ducts .
num .
pressurize duct to num psi using oilfree and waterfree compressed air .
a .
only one duct per web or girder may be tested at a time .
num .
lock off the outside air source .
num .
record pressure loss for num minute .
a .
locate the leak repair and retest if the pressure loss exceeds num psi for tendons greater than num ft long or num psi for tendons less than or equal to num ft long .
num .
include location and method of repair in duct air test records if repairs are required .
num .
do not load strand until all pressure tests are successful .
c. strands in an individual tendon may be pushed or pulled through the duct individually or may be pulled through the duct as a unit .
num .
protect the strand which is being advanced into the duct from contact with abrasive materials such as steel or concrete and contaminants such as grease oil and dirt at all times .
a .
round off ends of strands and wires that are pushed or fit advancing end with smooth protective cap .
b .
use pulling lines with a capacity of at least num times the dead weight of the tendons when used for essentially horizontal tendon installation .
c. do not use pushing wheels made from metal .
d. do not intentionally rotate strands or wires during installation .
e. use a special steel wire sock or other device attached to advancing end if a tendon is pulled through the duct .
f. do not install permanent tendons before completion of testing as required by this section .
num stressing tendons a .
general num .
do not apply pt forces until the concrete has attained the required compressive strength as shown .
a .
do not apply pt forces to castinplace concrete structures other than segmentally constructed bridges until num days after the last concrete has been placed in the member .
implementation num posttensioning concrete num page num of num january num num b .
make test cylinders for determining strength of the same concrete and cured under the same conditions as the member .
num .
stress all strands in each tendon simultaneously with a multistrand jack except for those in flat ducts with not more than four strands .
num .
furnish equipment for tensioning the tendons from the manufacturer of the pt system .
num .
sequence the stressing of posttension castinplace bridge such that no more than one tendon is stressed per web before stressing a tendon in another web .
a .
do not apply an eccentric force about the centerline of the structure that exceeds num of the total posttensioning force at any time during the prestressing .
num .
keep stressing operation records that include the following for each tendon installed a .
project pin name and number b .
contractor and subcontractor c. tendon location size and type d. date tendon was first installed in ducts e. coil and reel number for strands or wires and heat number for bars and wire f. assumed and actual crosssectional area g. assumed and actual modulus of elasticity h. date stressed i. jack and gauge numbers per end of tendon j .
required jacking force k. gauge pressures l. elongations theoretical and actual m. anchor sets theoretical and actual n. stressing sequence for example tendons before and after this tendon o. stressing mode one end or two ends or simultaneous p. witnesses to stressing operation contractor manufacturers representative and inspector q .
date grouted days from stressing to grouting grouting pressure applied and injection end r. other relevant information b. stressing jacks num .
use hydraulic jacks to stress tendons that are capable of providing and sustaining the necessary forces .
equip each jack with either a .
a pressure gauge with an accurately reading dial at least num inches in diameter .
implementation num posttensioning concrete num page num of num january num num b .
a load cell with indicator by means of which the prestressing force in the tendon may be determined .
num do not use the lower num percent of the manufacturers rated capacity when determining the jacking stress .
num .
use a jacking system that provides an independent means of measuring the tendon elongation .
c. tensioning operations num .
tension prestressing steel so that the force of the prestressing steel will not be less than the value shown on the authorized shop drawings .
a .
do not exceed num percent of the guaranteed ultimate tensile strength of the prestressing steel during the stressing of the tendons .
num replace tendons stressed past num percent of the guaranteed ultimate tensile strength .
b. anchor the prestressing steel at initial stresses that will result in the long term retention of permanent forces of not less than those shown on the approved shop drawings .
c. do not allow the initial stress at the anchorage to exceed num percent of guaranteed ultimate tensile strength after anchor set .
num .
remove and replace strand due to wire failure or slipping during stressing if any of the following conditions are met a .
member cross section has a final effective pt force less than num percent of the design total pt force based on the recorded jacking force or liftoff force whichever is smaller .
b. pt force across a mating joint is less than num percent of pt force required by the contract drawings for that mating joint for that stage of construction .
num this requirement applies to segmental construction or similar construction that has members post tensioned together across a common joint face at any stage of construction .
c. any single tendon has more than a num percent reduction in crosssectional area or posttensioning steel due to wire failure .
num .
follow stressing sequence shown in authorized shop drawings .
d. elongations num .
conduct the tensioning process such that tension being applied and the elongation of the posttensioning steel can be measured at all times .
num .
keep a permanent record of gauge pressures and tendon elongations for each tendon .
num .
measure elongations to the nearest num inch .
implementation num posttensioning concrete num page num of num january num num num .
preload tendons to num percent of their final jacking force before beginning elongation readings to eliminate takeup in the tensioning system .
num .
mark each strand before final stressing to permit measurement of elongation and to verify that all anchor wedges set properly .
num .
the measured elongation must agree within num percent of the theoretical elongation for the posttensioned elements to verify the required tendon force or the entire operation must be checked and the source of the error determined and remedied to the satisfaction of the department before proceeding with the work .
a .
do not overstress the tendon to achieve the theoretical elongation .
b .
acceptance may be achieved by force verification liftoff tests demonstrating that the measured force is within minus num percent and plus num percent of the required force as shown if the measured elongations fall outside of the acceptable tolerance .
num .
do not cut off the stressing tails of the tendons until the elongations have been approved by the pt system manufacturers representative .
within num hours of approval a .
cut prestressing steel using an abrasive saw or plasma torch to within  inch to num inch from anchorage .
num flame cutting of pt steel is not permitted .
b .
clean rust and other debris from metal surfaces which will be covered by the grout cap c. place grout cap including a seal over the wedge place until the tendon is grouted .
e. protection of steel after installation num .
minor rust which may form on the surface of the prestressing steel within num calendar days after protective packaging has been opened will not be cause for rejection .
num .
prestressing steel installed tensioned and grouted within num calendar days will not require the use of corrosion inhibitor in the duct following installation of the prestressing steel .
a .
blow a vapor phase corrosion inhibitor powder conforming to milprfnum into ducts containing prestressing steel if prestressing steel is anticipated to be removed from protective packaging for num days or more before grouting .
num .
do not exceed num calendar days between removal of prestressing steel from protective packaging and grouting operations .
a .
failure to begin grouting operations will result in stoppage of work .
implementation num posttensioning concrete num page num of num january num num num grouting a .
general num .
begin grouting operations to fill the void space between the duct and the tendons as soon as possible after all the prestressing steel has been tensioned anchored and approved by the pt system manufacturers representative .
num .
flush the inside of the duct with water under pressure to remove all traces of the corrosion inhibitor used to protect the prestressing steel if a vapor phase corrosion inhibitor has been blown into ducts before grouting .
a .
continue flushing operations until the discharge water is free of traces of the corrosion inhibitor .
b .
blow all water out of the duct with oilfree compressed air and swab dry after flushing .
num .
eliminate vibration from all sources under the contractors control within num ft of the member being grouted for the duration of the grouting procedure and num hours after completion .
num .
conduct a joint meeting of the contractor grouting crew and the engineer before grouting operations begin .
a .
discuss the grouting operation plan required testing corrective procedures and other relevant issues at the meeting .
b .
temperature num .
keep pt grout below num degrees f during mixing or pumping .
a .
cool the mixing water if necessary .
num .
keep ducts free of water to avoid damage due to freezing in temperatures below num degrees f. num .
keep accurate temperature records covering maximum and minimum air temperatures and temperatures of the concrete adjacent to the ducts to be grouted when ambient temperature may be expected to fall below num degrees f. num .
do not use any material in which frost or ice is present and keep the ducts and equipment free of frost and ice .
num .
postpone grouting operations if frost is expected within num hours of start .
num .
maintain a temperature of at least num degrees in the grout in the ducts for the duration of the grouting and the longer of num hours after completion or until jobcured num inch cubes of pt grout reach a minimum compressive strength of num psi when low temperatures are expected and grouting can not be postponed .

num .

e. grouting operations num .
blow oilfree and waterfree compressed air through the ducts checking all inlet and outlet pipes to verify they are capable of accepting injection of the pt grout immediately before grouting .
num .
open all inlet and outlet ports before grouting starts .
num .
obtain target flow rates as a function of mixer type used and ambient temperatures from the pt grout manufacturer .
a. verify the grouting rate is slow enough to avoid air entrapment and segregation of the grout and verify complete filling of the duct .
num .
maintain a continuous oneway flow of pt grout in a generally uphill direction .
a .
inject pt grout from near the lowest end of tendons .
b. grout each tendon in one operation .
c. flush the grout out of the duct with water immediately when oneway flow of grout can not be maintained or grouting is interrupted .
num .
refer to pti mnum section num for production test requirements of production grout .
num .
perform normal operations at approximately num psi .
num .
do not exceed a pumping pressure at the tendon inlet of a .
num psi for internal polyethylene ducts b .
num psi for internal circular steel ducts implementation num posttensioning concrete num page num of num january num num c. num psi for external hdpe pipe d. close the inlet and inject the pt grout at the next outlet which now becomes an inlet which has just been or is ready to be closed as long as a oneway flow is maintained if the actual grouting pressure exceeds the maximum allowed .
num fit the outlet that is to be used for injection with a positive shutoff .
num do not inject grout into a succeeding outlet from which grout has not yet flowed .
num .
waste grout through the first outlet after the inlet pipe until residual water or entrapped air has been removed a .
cap or otherwise close outlet when the consistency of the ejected grout is the same as the injected grout .
b .
close following remaining outlets in the same manner except at high points where the outlets a short distance downstream to the high point are closed before the high point outlet .
c. discharge at least num gallons of grout through the final outlet pipe before sealing .
num .
provide a standpipe at the upper end of the duct for vertical or nearly vertical tendons .
a .
design the standpipe to collect and store bleed water and allow it to be removed from the grout .
b .
locate the standpipe so that the level of the grout can be brought to an elevation so that bleeding will not cause the level of the grout to drop below the highest point of the upper anchorage device .
c. remove the standpipe after the grout has hardened .
num .
do not remove or open plugs caps or valves until the pt grout has set .
a .

b .

c. remove all miscellaneous material used for sealing grout caps before carrying our further work to protect anchorages .
d. permanently seal all outlet and inlet openings for external tendons .

randomly inspect num percent of the inlet and outlet pipes at anchorage and at high points for voids by drilling and inspecting with a borescope .
a .
inspect ducts between num and num hours after grouting .
b .
use drilling equipment that will automatically shut off when steel is encountered to prevent damaging the prestressing steel and anchorages .
c. all anchorages and high points will be inspected if a void exposing prestressing steel is found by random drilling .
d. fill drilled holes not indicating voids with epoxy compound within num hours of completion of inspections .
num use an injection tube to fill drilled hole from the base .
e. use vacuum grouting to fill voids that expose prestressing steel .
num perform vacuum grouting operations under the direct supervision of a crew foreman who has been trained and has experience in the use of vacuum grouting equipment and procedures .

num forms a. plywood wood metal glass or a combination of these materials .
b .
use mortartight concrete forms true to the dimensions lines and grades of the structure and of sufficient rigidity to prevent objectional distortion of the formed concrete surface caused by pressure of the concrete and other loads incidental to the construction operations .
c. discontinue using a form or forming system that produces a concrete surface with excessive undulations until modifications have been made .
num .
undulations are excessive if they exceed either  inch over num feet or num of the centertocenter distance between studs joints forms fasteners or wales .
d. countersink all bolt and rivet holes when using metal forms for exposed surfaces so that a plane smooth surface of the desired contour is obtained .
e. use lumber that is free of knotholes loose knots cracks splits warps or other defects that affect the strength or appearance of the structure .
num .
rough lumber may be used for forming surfaces if visible rough surfaces do not show on the final structure .
implementation num structural concrete num page num of num january num num f. form exposed element surfaces of a concrete structure with the same forming material or with materials that produce a concrete surface that is uniform in texture color and appearance .
g. do not use stayinplace metal deck forms unless otherwise specified .

refer to section num part num execution num preparation a. falsework num .
design and construct falsework according to the aashto lrfd bridge construction specifications section num temporary works .
a .
design falsework so that loads imposed on existing new or partially completed portions of structures due to construction operations do not exceed the load carrying capacity of the structure or portion of the structure .
b. brace and tie girders to resist forces that would cause rotation or torsion in the girders from the placing of concrete for diaphragms or decks or show girders to be adequate for those effects .
c. do not weld falsework support brackets or braces to structural steel members or to reinforcing steel .
num .
footing construction a .
build falsework on a solid footing that is safe against undermining protected from softening and capable of supporting imposed loads .
b .
demonstrate that the soil bearing values do not exceed the supporting capacity of the soil .
num conduct load tests or have soils investigation conducted by a professional engineer licensed in the state of utah .
implementation num structural concrete num page num of num january num num c. use piling or drilled shafts to support falsework that can not be founded on a solid footing .
d. space drive and remove piles according to the authorized falsework drawings .
num .
construction a .
use materials able to sustain the stresses required by the falsework design .
b .
use suitable jacks or wedges to set the forms to the grade or camber required and to prevent settling .
c. produce a finished structure of the specified camber and built to the lines and grades indicated .
b .
forms num .
clean the inside surfaces of dirt mortar and foreign material before concrete placement .
num .
use form oil that permits the ready release of the forms and does not discolor the concrete .
num .
do not place concrete in the forms until a .
all work connected with form construction has been completed .
b .
all embedded materials have been placed .
c. all dirt chips sawdust water and other foreign materials have been removed .
d. inspection and approval have been obtained .
num .
do not use stayinplace deck forms unless otherwise specified .
c. footings box culverts and headwalls num .
excavation and backfill refer to section num .
num .
the engineer may direct written changes in dimensions or elevations necessary to secure a satisfactory foundation .
num .
do not dewater by pumping during concrete placement or for num hours thereafter unless pumping is outside the enclosure .
num .
do not use well points to dewater footing .
d. bridge decks num .
reinforcing steel a .
pass the screed over the area with a screed face device to measure the cover before concrete placement .
b .
relocate and tie reinforcing steel that projects above the specified level before placing the concrete .
c. adjust and support reinforcing steel that does not meet the placement tolerances defined in section num before placing the concrete .
implementation num structural concrete num page num of num january num num num .
screeds a .
firmly support screed rails for bridge deck slabs to prevent movement during concrete placement .
b .
support the machine rails on the bridge beams when using a finishing machine .
c. do not place the machine rails on the forms unless the form supports have been strengthened to prevent deflection and the engineer gives authorization .
e. miscellaneous construction num .
drainage and weep holes a. construct drainage and weep holes at locations shown or as directed .
b .
place ports or vents for equalizing hydrostatic pressure below low water .
c. use noncorrosive materials for weep hole forms .
d. paint exposed surfaces of metal drains as shown .
num .
anchor bolts a. securely and accurately set anchor bolts in bent caps abutments or pedestals before the concrete is placed .
b .
use templates to maintain location and plumbness .
num place concrete a .
do not place concrete without authorization from the engineer .
b .
do not deviate from the deck placing sequence shown without written authorization from the engineer .
c. the engineer may postpone placement operations if the concrete can not be protected during adverse weather .
d. handling concrete num .
avoid segregation of the ingredients .
num .
arrange chutes troughs or pipes used as aids in placing concrete so the concrete does not separate .
num .
use metal or metallined chutes and troughs .
do not use aluminum .
num .
equip chutes with baffle boards or a reversed section at the end of the outlet when placing on steep slopes .
num .
extend open troughs and chutes down inside the forms or through holes left in the forms .
terminate the ends in vertical downspouts .
num .
thoroughly flush all chutes troughs and pipes with water before and after each placement .
implementation num structural concrete num page num of num january num num num .
do not allow the free fall of concrete to exceed num ft for thin walls maximum num inch thickness or num ft for other types of construction without the use of a tremie or a flexible metal spout .
num .
use flexible metal spout sections composed of conical sections not more than num ft long with the diameter of the outlet and the taper of the various sections so the concrete fills the outlet and retards concrete flow .
e. placing concrete num .
deposit concrete as close as possible to its final position without allowing it to flow laterally in the form .
num .
spread fresh concrete in horizontal layers with thickness not greater than what can be compacted with vibrators .
num .
do not use vibrators to flow concrete laterally .
num .
limit placement interruptions to num minutes .
num .
place and vibrate each layer before the preceding layer has taken initial set .
num .
do not place concrete in flowing water .
f. consolidating concrete num .
use high frequency internal vibrators to consolidate all concrete for structures except concrete placed under water .
num .
use enough vibrators to consolidate the fresh concrete to the desired degree within num minutes after it is deposited in the forms .
num .
supply at least two vibrators for structures involving more than num ydnum of concrete .
num .
do not attach vibrators to or against the forms or the reinforcing steel .
num .
do not allow vibrators to penetrate layers of concrete that have taken initial set .
num .
use spades or wedgeshaped tampers to secure a smooth and even texture of the exposed surface .
num place concrete under water a .
place and deposit concrete under water as shown .
b. seal the forms or cofferdams watertight .
c. do not pump water while placing concrete or disturb the concrete until it has set at least num hours or attained at least num percent of the specified num day minimum compressive strength based on field cured cylinders .
d. regulate placing to keep surfaces approximately horizontal at all times .
implementation num structural concrete num page num of num january num num e. place the concrete by beginning at one end of the form and progressing in a zigzag movement from side to side across the length of the form .
f. place the concrete using a tremie or concrete pumping equipment .
g. placing concrete with a tremie num .
use an num inch to num inch diameter steel tube tremie constructed with watertight connections a hopper to receive concrete and a device at the bottom to exclude water from entering the tube .
num .
use support that permits the discharge end to move over the entire top work surface and permits the tremie to be rapidly lowered to stop or retard flow when necessary .
num .
minimize the number of tremie location shifts for continuous placement .
num .
keep the tremie tube full to the bottom of the hopper during placement .
num .
slightly raise the tremie when a batch is dumped into the hopper but do not raise it out of the concrete at the bottom until the batch discharges to the bottom of the hopper .
a. replug the end and refill the tube with concrete if the concrete seal around the tube is lost .
num pump concrete a .
use a prequalified concrete pumping contractor .
refer to udot quality management plan num concrete pumping .
num .
replace pump that causes excessive or erratic loss of air entrainment .
num .
use a pump that produces a continuous stream of concrete without air pockets .
num .
do not add water to the concrete in the pump hopper .
b .
do not allow pump vibrations to damage freshly placed concrete .
c. do not use concrete contaminated by priming or cleaning the pump .
num limitations a .
light the work site so all operations are plainly visible if mixing placing or finishing occurs after daylight hours .
b .
keep all traffic off concrete bridges and culverts for num days after final concrete placement until all concrete is fully cured and until all concrete achieves num percent of the specified num day minimum compressive strength based on field cured cylinders .
implementation num structural concrete num page num of num january num num c. keep all traffic off bridge deck and approach slab closure pours for at least num days after final concrete placement until all concrete is fully cured and until all concrete achieves num percent of the specified num day minimum compressive strength based on field cured cylinders .
num .
highearly strength concrete used in bridge deck and approach slab closure pours may be opened to traffic at least num days after final concrete placement and after concrete achieves num percent of the specified num day minimum compressive strength based on field cured cylinders .
num construction joints a .
make construction joints where shown .
b .
obtain engineers authorization when additional construction joints are desired and meet the following requirements num .
place and construct without impairing strength and appearance .
num .
place in planes perpendicular to the principal lines of stress and at points of minimum shear .
num .
make monolithic structures by extending the reinforcing across the joint .
num .
avoid construction joints through paneled wing walls or large surfaces that are to be treated architecturally .
num .
make a straight line joint across the face of the pour for the full width of the bridge deck .
num .
leave a rough surface to increase the bond with the concrete placed later .
num .
form tapered sections with an insert so that the succeeding layer of concrete ends in a section at least num inches thick .
num .
place a bulkhead from the surface to the top mat of steel to establish a straight vertical face .
shape the concrete below the top steel to a near vertical face in line with the bulkhead .
num .
establish a straight vertical face by saw cutting to a minimum depth of num inch when a bulkhead can not be placed .
a .
shape the concrete below the saw cut to a near vertical face .
c. meet the following before resuming concrete placement num .
retighten forms .
num .
roughen the surface of hardened concrete without leaving loosened particles or damaged concrete .
num .
clean off concrete surface of foreign matter and laitance by sandblasting .
num .
saturate concrete surface with water .
num .
apply epoxy adhesive to face of construction joints .
implementation num structural concrete num page num of num january num num num concrete surface finishing classifications a .
ordinary surface finish a true and uniform finished surface .
b .
rubbed finish a surface smooth in texture and uniform in appearance free of form marks and irregularities .
c. wire brush or scrubbed finish num .
a finished surface with the cement surface film completely removed and the aggregate particles exposed leaving an evenpebbled texture .
num .
an appearance ranging from fine granite to coarse conglomerate depends on the size and grading of the aggregate used .
d. floated surface finish num .
flat work strike off and use a floated surface finish .
num .
bridge decks and approach slabs machine finish unless otherwise permitted .
num concrete surface finishing a .
give all formed concrete surfaces at least an ordinary surface finish except as specified otherwise .
b .
use other types of finishes as required in addition to the ordinary surface finish .
c. provide a rubbed finish for repaired surfaces that can not meet ordinary surface finish requirements due to irregularities honeycombing excessive surface voids discoloration and other defects .
num concrete surface finishing procedures a .
ordinary surface finish num .
remove all fins and projections after removing forms .
a .
clean point and true all honeycomb spots broken corners or edges cavities made by form ties and other holes and defects .
b .
keep all areas to receive mortar saturated with water for at least num minutes before mortar placement .
num .
use a mortar of cement and fine aggregate for pointing not more than one hour old mixed in the proportions used in the grade of concrete being finished .
num .
cure the mortar patches and rub to blend with surrounding concrete .
implementation num structural concrete num page num of num january num num num .
tool and free all joints of mortar and concrete .
a .
leave the full length of the joint filler exposed with clean and true edges .
b .
rubbed finish num .
wet the concrete surface as soon after form removal as conditions permit paint with grout and rub with a wooden float until the surface is covered with a lather of cement and water .
a .
a thin grout of one part cement one part fine sand may be used in the rubbing .
b .
let this lather set for at least three days then rub lightly with a fine carborundum stone until smooth .
num .
use a mechanically operated carborundum stone to finish the surface of hardened concrete at least four days after placing .
a .
finish in the same manner as ordinary surface finish .
num let the lather set for at least num days before lightly rubbing with a fine carborundum stone until smooth .
num .
commercial grade rubbing mortar may be used if authorized by engineer .
c. wire brush or scrubbed finish num .
scrub the surface with stiff wire or fiber brushes using a solution of muriatic acid one part acid four parts water as soon as forms are removed and while the concrete is relatively green .
num .
wash the entire surface once the scrubbing produces the desired texture .
a .
use water mixed with num percent by volume ammonium hydroxide to remove all traces of the acid .
d. floated surface finish on flat work other than bridge decks and approach slabs num .
striking off a .
carefully rod and strike off the surface with a strike board following the cross sections and grades shown after compaction .
b .
allow for camber as required .
c. operate the strike board longitudinally or transversely and move it forward with a combined longitudinal and transverse motion so that neither end is raised from the side forms during the process .
d. keep a slight excess of concrete in front of the cutting edge at all times .
num .
floating a .
use longitudinal or transverse floating or both to create a uniform surface .
implementation num structural concrete num page num of num january num num b. longitudinal floating is required except in places where it is not feasible .
num .
longitudinal floating a .
work the longitudinal float operated from foot bridges with a sawing motion while holding it parallel to the road centerline .
b .
pass gradually from one side of the pavement to the other .
num move the float forward  of its length and repeat operation .
c. substitute machine floating if equivalent results are produced .
num .
transverse floating a .
operate the transverse float across the concrete surface by starting at the edge and slowly moving to the center and back again to the edge .
num move the float forward  of its length and repeat the operation .
b .
preserve the crown and cross section of the concrete surface .
num .
straightedging a .
test the concrete surface for trueness with a straightedge after the longitudinal floating has been completed and the excess water has been removed while the concrete is still plastic .
b. furnish and use an accurate num ft straightedge held parallel to the road centerline in contact with the surface .
c. check the entire area immediately filling depressions with freshly mixed concrete then strike off consolidate and refinish .
d. cut down and refinish high areas .
e. continue the straightedge testing and refloating until the concrete surface is at the required grade and contour .
e. floated surface finish for bridge decks and approach slabs num .
machine finish exposed surfaces unless otherwise permitted .
num .
finish concrete by striking off and floating the surface .
num .
allow the engineer enough time to inspect finishing machines during daylight hours before concrete placement .
num .
provide lighting facilities that adequately light the work area when placing and finishing operations are not completed during daylight hours .
num .
extend finishing machine rails beyond both ends of the scheduled placement and allow sufficient distance to permit the float to fully clear the concrete .
implementation num structural concrete num page num of num january num num num .
use adjustable rails set to provide the finished grade elevations shown installed to prevent springing or deflection under the weight of the finishing equipment and placed to operate without interruption over the entire surface being finished .
num .
place screed machine parallel to the abutments and bents within num degrees .
num .
support screed rails to prevent movement during placing of the concrete .
num .
attach a measuring device to the screed face and pass it over the area .
num .
place concrete in a uniform heading approximately parallel to the screed machine .
num .
limit the rate of placing to allow enough time to finish the surface before initial set .
num .
continuously place concrete the full length of the structure or superstructure unit unless otherwise shown or authorized .
num .
provide sufficient material equipment and manpower to place deck concrete at a rate of at least num ydnumhour .
num .
strike off the surface to the required elevations with the finishing machine immediately after placing and consolidating the concrete .
num .
do not add water to the concrete in front of or behind the screed .
num .
obtain authorization for the strikeoff method and equipment .
a .
maintain satisfactory performance .
b .
use equipment capable of finishing concrete within the surface tolerances specified .
c. maintain satisfactory consolidation and surface tolerance to prevent shutdown and rejection of the equipment .
num .
furnish a num ft straightedge to check the surface tolerance placed both longitudinally and transversely immediately behind the screed machine and handfinished areas .
num .
correct irregularities greater than  inch from the straightedge before additional placement and immediately fill depressions with concrete and refinish .
num .
cut down and refinish high areas .
num .
continue straightedge testing and corrective measures until the entire surface is free of observable departures from the straightedge .
f. final texturing for bridge decks and approach slabs a textured hardened finish num .
use a texture process that produces regular  inch wide transverse grooves spaced randomly from  inch to  inch on centers and  inch deep .
num .
keep the finished surface free from porous spots and surface irregularities .
implementation num structural concrete num page num of num january num num num .
furnish a work bridge that follows the finishing machine to facilitate texturing and application of the curing compound .
num .
check the surface smoothness for acceptance after the concrete has hardened .
num .
remove irregularities by grinding if the surface deviates more than  inch from a num ft straightedge .
refer to section num. a .
depth of grinding must be authorized by the engineer before any grinding operations begin .
num concrete curing a .
refer to section num .
num form removal a .
obtain authorization from the engineer before removing forms .
b .
remove struts stays and braces that hold the forms in correct shape and alignment when no longer necessary .
c. remove all forms from the concrete surfaces .
num .
do not use a method of form removal likely to cause overstressing of the concrete .
d. remove supports to permit the concrete to uniformly and gradually take the stresses due to its own weight .
e. do not remove forms used in ornamental work railings parapets and exposed vertical surfaces for at least twelve hours after placement .
f. always remove forms before removing shoring from beneath beams and girders to determine the condition of columns .
g. removing falsework num .
do not remove falsework supporting the deck of rigid frame structures until the fill has been placed in back of the vertical legs .
num .
keep falsework and forms in place under slabs beams and girders for num days after the day of last concrete placement .
a. slab forms with a clear space of less than num ft may be removed after seven days .
num .
keep forms and falsework in place in cold weather according to the authorized cold weather concreting plan .
implementation num structural concrete num page num of num january num num h. patch formed surfaces within num hours after form removal .
num .
cut back and remove all projecting wire or metal devices used for holding the forms in place and that pass through the body of the concrete at least num inch beneath the surface of the concrete .
num .
remove lips of mortar and irregularities caused by form joints .
num .
fill small holes depressions and voids with cement mortar mixed in the same proportions as that used in the body of the work .
num .
obtain a solid uniform surface by chipping away coarse or broken material to patch larger holes or honeycombs .
a .
cut away feathered edges to form faces perpendicular to the surface .
b .
apply epoxy adhesive to patch area according to manufacturers recommendations .
c. fill the cavity with stiff mortar composed of one part portland cement to two parts sand thoroughly tamped into place .
d. preshrink the mortar by mixing it approximately num minutes .
num vary the time according to manufacturers recommendations temperature humidity and other local conditions .
e. float the surface of this mortar with a wooden float before initial set .
f. keep the patch wet for five days .
g. rub patches on exposed surfaces to blend them with surrounding concrete after curing .
h. add coarse aggregate to the patching material when patching large or deep areas .
i .
make a dense wellbonded and properly cured patch .
i .
areas with extensive honeycombing will be rejected .
j .
apply the following requirements after fully removing all the closure joint forms if inserts are placed along the bottom edges of the precast concrete deck panels to form the closure pour joints num .
cut off castinplace anchors at least num inch below the face of slab and repair according to this section article num paragraph h. num .
fill all voids with drypack mortar flush with the bottom of slab .
num .
fill voids created by the removal of reusable concrete anchors with drypack mortar flush with the bottom of slab .
num .
drypack mortar will be composed of one part portland cement to two parts sand .
implementation num structural concrete num page num of num january num num num superstructure a. deck do not place parapet forms or parapet for at least seven days after deck placement and until the deck has attained the specified num day minimum compressive strength based on field cured cylinders or leave all falsework in place and design it to carry all additional loads that are part of the parapet placement process .
num .
do not allow the installation of the parapet and parapet forms to interrupt the curing of the deck and approach slabs when installed before curing is complete .
b. slab span place concrete in one continuous operation .
c. castinplace tbeams num .
place concrete in one or two continuous operations first to the top of the girder stems and second to completion unless otherwise shown .
num .
obtain a bond between the stem and slab that is positive and mechanical and secured by means of shear keys or roughened surface in the top of the girder stem .
d. do not place the approach slab until the sleeper slab concrete has been in place at least seven days or has attained num percent of the specified num day compressive strength based on field cured cylinders .
num substructure a .
concrete in columns and bent stems num .

num .

num .

num .
do not place concrete in the superstructure until the columns have been stripped and authorized .
b. substructure concrete num .

implementation num structural concrete num page num of num january num num c. do not backfill abutments wingwalls and retaining walls until all concrete has been in place at least num days and has attained num percent of the specified num day minimum compressive strength based on field cured cylinders .
num .
do not interfere with curing .
num box culverts a .
allow base slab and footing to attain num percent of the specified num day minimum compressive strength based upon field cured cylinders before constructing the remainder of the culvert .
b. construct side walls and top slab monolithically unless the wall height exceeds num ft. num .
keep the construction joints vertical and at right angles to the axis of the culvert .
c. construct shear keys in the top of the side walls for anchoring the top slab when side walls and top slab are not placed monolithically .
d. construct wingwalls monolithically .
e. do not backfill until the concrete has been in place at least num days and has attained num percent of the specified num day minimum compressive strength based on field cured cylinders .
f. apply a waterproofing membrane to the top slab and side walls of all concrete box culverts for the full length of the structures .
num headwalls a .
allow apron and pipe collar to attain num percent of the specified num day minimum compressive strength based on field cured cylinders before the remainder of the headwall is constructed .
b. construct wingwalls monolithically .
c. do not backfill headwalls and wingwalls until all concrete has been in place at least num days and has attained num percent of the specified num day minimum compressive strength based on field cured cylinders .

num preparation and installation of structural nonshrink grout a .
clean and remove debris from the camber strips and blockouts before placing the structural nonshrink grout .
b .
keep bonding surfaces free from laitance dirt dust paint grease oil rust or contaminant other than water .
c. form the girder camber strips as shown after installing shear studs at the locations shown .
d. pretest grout material installation under field conditions in a grout pocket and camber strip mockup to determine grout flowability and whether subsequent cracking will occur .
include in the mockup at least two shear stud pockets and a camber strip that is the same configuration as the actual bridge .
num .
the engineer may determine modifications to the grouting process .
num .
proceed with grouting process as modified by the engineer .
e. saturate surface dry ssd surfaces receiving structural nonshrink grout .
f. mix and place structural nonshrink grout following manufacturers recommendations for preparation and installation .
num .

num .
place structural nonshrink grout in the girder camber strips in a continuous operation within a panel .
h. grout the shear stud blockouts using structural nonshrink grout .
num .
structural nonshrink grout in the shear stud blockouts can be placed as part of the placement of the structural nonshrink grout in the girder camber strips .
i .
do not allow voids in the grout for the girder camber strips and shear stud blockouts .

num related sections a .
section num concrete slab jacking b .
section num bridge concrete grinding c. section num portland cement concrete d. section num selfconsolidating concrete scc e. section num reinforcing steel and welded wire f. section num structural concrete g. section num concrete curing h. section num flowable fill num references a. aashto m num zinc hotdip galvanized coatings on iron and steel products b. aashto m num preformed sponge rubber and cork expansion joint fillers for concrete paving and structural construction c. aashto m num preformed expansion joint filler for concrete paving and structural construction nonextruding and resilient bituminous types d. aashto t num compressive strength of hydraulic cement mortars using numin .
cube specimens implementation num precast approach slabs num page num of num january num num e. aashto t num length change of hardened hydraulic cement mortar and concrete f. aashto t num resistance of concrete to rapid freezing and thawing g. astm c num rigid cellular polystyrene thermal insulation h. astm c num bond strength of epoxyresin systems used with concrete by slant shear i. astm c num packaged dry rapidhardening cementitious materials for concrete repairs j. astm d num polyethylene films made from lowdensity polyethylene for general use and packaging applications k. pci design handbook l. udot quality management plan num definitions a .
approach slab a structural slab that is designed to span from the rear face of the abutment to the sleeper slab .
the purpose of approach slabs is to span over potential settlement of the bridge abutment backfill .
the soil under the slab is not intended to support the slab .
support is provided by the bridge abutment and the sleeper slab .
b. sleeper slab a structural slab that is designed as a transition from the approach slab to the approach roadway pavement .
the sleeper slab bears directly on the subgrade and supports the end of the approach slab .
the expansion joint between the sleeper slab and the approach slab is used to accommodate the thermal movement of the bridge .

working drawings num .

num minimum compressive strength required before handling the precast elements .

international concrete repair institute icri num definitions a. polymer overlay system a thin bonded polymer overlay applied as a wearing surface consisting of a twopart polymer resin broadcasted with aggregate to refusal before it cures .
b. installer the entity preparing the surface and installing and finishing the polymer overlay system .
c. provider the manufacturer furnishing the polymer overlay system .

implementation num thin bonded polymer overlay num page num of num january num num num application a .
concrete surface num .

num .

num .

num .
verify the moisture content in the concrete substrate does not exceed num percent when measured by an electronic meter .
num .
apply the polymer overlay system only when the deck and ambient air temperature is a minimum num degrees f and rising .
num .
verify that treated surfaces are dry at the time of second application .

measure and mix the polymer resin components as recommended by the provider .
a .
maintain mix ratios according to the providers recommendations .
num .
mix polymer resin immediately before dispensing .
num .
verify the mix ratio by volumetric sampling at the beginning of the application mid operation and at the end of the application of each layer .
a .
use containers with graduated markings with not less than num gallon capacity .
b .
remove the static mixer and dispense each component into separate containers .
num dispense at least five gallons of the primary component for ratio comparison .
num uncontaminated samples may be returned to the reservoirs they were originally dispensed from .
c. the engineer or technical support representative may request additional sampling .

implementation num move bridge num page num of num january num num num monitor the bridge through a typical daily temperature cycle using the monitoring system used during the move .
a record measurements just before dawn of each day and when the bridge reaches the approximate maximum temperature .
b .
immediately before the initial lift .
num record the initial measurements .
a initial measurements establish the baseline condition of the bridge .
c. immediately after the initial lift .
num record measurements and compare the bridge to the baseline condition .
num calculate the deflection change as the difference between the condition just before to just after the initial lifting of the bridge .
num verify that measurements are within tolerance limits .
d. during the bridge move num continuously monitor the bridge .
e. when the bridge is aligned and ready for setting but is not in contact with the final supports .
f. after setting the bridge in its permanent location .
num record a final set of monitoring system measurements .
num verify that measurements are within anticipated and allowable tolerance limits specified for permanent elevations .
d. limit deflection change twist and other measurements to the limits defined in the authorized monitoring plan .

technical support representative num .

a .

b .
the department reserves the right to require the technical support representative to be onsite if at any time the engineer is concerned with the product installation quality .

num num part num execution num surface preparation a .
do not begin surface preparation until skid resistance testing has been performed .
b. shotblasting num .
clean the concrete surface by automatic shotblasting .
remove all traces of curing compound laitance grease dirt dust salt oil asphalt paint striping coating or foreign materials .
a .
use a cleaning unit equipped with a dust collector that recycles the abrasives .
b .
do not gouge the surface during shotblasting operations .
c. collect and dispose of the removed concrete surfacing .
d. clean the surface and cracks with oil free compressed air .
refer to astm d num .
c. perform additional surface preparation if recommended by the technical support representative .
d. cover deck joints plug deck drains and scuppers seal cracks on underside of deck and use other protective measures to protect waterways and bridge components. . e. do not allow traffic on the deck that has been shotblasted .
implementation num bridge deck methacrylate resin treatment num page num of num january num num installation a .
install according to the requirements in this section .
num .
follow the providers recommendations that are more stringent than the requirements listed in this section .
b .
the deck surface must be dry at the time of hmwm resin treatment .
c. pretreat visible cracks by filling the cracks and keeping them full .
num .
prefill large cracks wider than num inch with sand before applying resin .
num .
treat crack by ponding resin over the crack for between num and num minutes allowing gravity to feed material into the crack .
num .
repeat ponding procedure until each crack is sealed .
d. mix the hmwm resin components according to the providers requirements and apply the resin to the deck within five minutes of completing mixing .
e. evenly distribute the hmwm resin on the clean dry deck surface at the providers recommended rate but not greater than num ftnumgal .
num .
application rates may vary depending on field conditions .
a. texture and absorption of the surface will determine final coverage rates .
b .
the technical support representative will assist the installer in determining application rates .
num .
apply the hmwm resin to refusal .
num .
redistribute excess material using squeegees or brooms .
f. broadcast silica sand mechanically over the entire treated area of the bridge deck to obtain a visually uniform coverage of at least num lbydnum .
num .
apply the sand before the resin gels .
num .
remove excess sand if required by the technical support representative .
num .
remove all loose sand that has accumulated along the face of the parapets in deck drains and expansion joints at least num calendar days after opening the hmwm resin treatment to traffic .
g. apply the material in the morning and evening hours when the temperatures are lower and the cracks are at their most open point .
num limitations a .
do not use material after the original shelf life date .
implementation num bridge deck methacrylate resin treatment num page num of num january num b .
cure concrete in new bridge decks for at least num days after placement before applying the hmwm resin treatment .
c. do not apply resin within num hours after a rain or when more than num percent probability of rain is forecast within num hours following the application .
d. conduct the work in a continuous operation with the hmwm resin treatment application immediately following surface preparation .
e. apply hmwm resin treatment only if the deck surface temperature and the air temperature are between num degrees f and num degrees f and the weather forecast shows air temperatures will remain within that range for at least twelve hours after the application is complete .
f. do not permit traffic on the treated surface until the silica sand cover adheres sufficiently to prevent tracking .

concrete curing materials and methods .
b .
this section does not apply to castinplace portland cement concrete pavement and lean concrete base course .
c. this section does not apply to dry cast precast concrete members except for precast concrete box and threesided culvert structures .
num related sections a .
section num portland cement concrete b .
section num structural concrete num references a. astm c num liquid membraneforming compounds for curing concrete b. astm c num liquid membraneforming compounds having special properties for curing and sealing concrete c. udot quality management plans num definitions not used num submittals a .

implementation num concrete curing num page num of num january num num part num products num curing compound a .
refer to this section part num tables num and num .
b .
limit volatile organic compounds voc content to num grams liter maximum .
part num execution num curing measures a .
prevent drying of exposed concrete surfaces after placing concrete and until applying the selected curing method .
num .
keep exposed concrete surfaces moist by fogging if the surfaces begin to dry before the selected curing method can be applied .
b .
cure newly placed concrete to prevent loss of water by one or more of the following methods according to this section .
num .
formsinplace method fipm a .
cure formed surfaces of concrete by retaining the forms in place without loosening for the specified curing period .
b .
complete the cure using one of the methods specified for the element when forms are removed before completing the specified curing period .
num .
water method wm a .
keep concrete surfaces continuously wet by ponding spraying or covering with materials that are continuously and thoroughly wet .
num acceptable materials for covering concrete surfaces include cotton mats multiple layers of burlap or other materials that retain water .
num secure the cover materials to prevent wind or other forces from removing them .
num keep the cover materials saturated throughout the curing period .
b .
do not erode or damage the finish .
c. prevent excess water from impacting traffic on inservice roadways .
implementation num concrete curing num page num of num january num num num .
liquid membranecuring compound method lmccm a .
thoroughly seal exposed concrete surfaces with a liquid membranecuring compound immediately after finishing operations are completed for exposed concrete surfaces or immediately after forms are removed and necessary patching is complete when forms are removed before the end of the curing period .
b .
apply liquid membranecuring compound uniformly at the rates specified in tables num and num. c. immediately repair damage to the curing compound film during the specified curing period by respraying .
num .
waterproof cover method wcm a .
exposed concrete surfaces must be wet before installing cover .
b .
cover exposed concrete surfaces with a material that prevents moisture loss from the concrete .
num do not use materials that have lost their waterproof qualities .
num secure cover to prevent displacement by wind .
c. use this method only when the covering can be secured adequately to prevent moisture loss .
d. maintain the air temperature beneath the cover at not less than num degrees f. num the use of insulated blankets is permitted .
num .
steam or radiantheat method srhm a .
use only for precast concrete members manufactured in prequalified plants .
b .
use a complete steam or radiant heat curing system that includes num hour temperature control and monitoring devices .
num use temperature recording devices as necessary to verify that temperatures are uniform throughout the enclosure and within the limits specified .
c. steam heat curing system num use a suitable enclosure to contain live steam and minimize moisture and heat losses .
num use lowpressure and saturated steam .
num maintain num to num percent relative humidity in the curing enclosure .
num do not apply heat directly on the concrete or cause localized high temperatures .
d. radiant heat curing system num apply heat by means of pipes circulating steam hot oil or hot water or by electric heating elements .
num use a suitable enclosure to contain the heat .
implementation num concrete curing num page num of num january num num num minimize moisture loss by covering exposed concrete surfaces with plastic sheeting .
e. waiting period num do not apply the initial application of heat before the initial set of the concrete except to maintain the minimum temperature within the curing enclosure .
num maintain the temperature within the curing enclosure at not less than num degrees f. a live steam or radiant heat may be used to maintain the curing enclosure at the proper minimum temperature .
b keep the concrete wet during this period .
f. curing period num increase the temperature within the concrete during the initial application of heat at an average rate not to exceed num degrees f per hour until the curing temperature is reached .
num do not exceed a concrete temperature of num degrees f when applying heat .
num maintain the concrete temperature at between num degrees f and num degrees f. num maintain the curing temperature until the concrete achieves the specified strength for terminating the curing .
num decrease the concrete temperature at a rate not to exceed num degrees f per hour until reaching a temperature of not more than num degrees f above the air temperature to which the concrete will be exposed when discontinuing heat .
g. transfer the stressing force to the concrete immediately after discontinuing steam curing or radiant heat curing for prestressed members .
c. prevent exposed concrete surfaces from drying when transitioning between curing methods .
d. fogging num .
use fogging when necessary to prevent drying of exposed concrete surfaces .
num .
use fogging equipment with compressed air misters that atomize the water and produce a very fine mist and not a spray .
a .
use equipment that allows for adjusting the rate of fogging depending on the conditions that are present .
b .
maintain misters at least num ft above the concrete surface and aimed in a direction not lower than horizontal .
implementation num concrete curing num page num of num january num num c. do not use fogging to apply excess water to the concrete surface to aid finishing .
d. do not affect the watercement ratio of the concrete .
e. discontinue fogging when a fine coating of water or sheen is visible on the concrete surface .
num .
do not damage the concrete surface .
e. follow the hot and cold weather limitations according to section num .
num curing compound application a .
comply with the following when applying liquid membranecuring compound to structural elements in bridges box culverts headwalls retaining walls concrete drainage structures and concrete slope protection .
num .
do not use curing compounds on surfaces that require a rubbed finish or on surfaces of construction joints against which new concrete will be cast unless approved .
a .
completely remove the curing compound before casting new concrete against the surface when curing compound is allowed .
num .
do not use curing compounds on architectural surfaces that require a concrete coating or penetrating concrete sealer and where removal will diminish the texture .
b .
preparation num .
verify concrete surfaces are ready for curing .
a .
complete all patching and surface finishing before applying curing compound .
num .
prepare concrete surfaces and apply curing compound according to product manufacturers recommendations .
refer to tables num and num for application rates .
num .
keep surfaces moist until the curing compound is applied .
num cure castinplace concrete a .
cure all formed surfaces using the fipm .
b .
cure exposed surfaces of newly placed castinplace concrete according to the curing methods and curing periods in table num .
num .
determine the concrete compressive strength using field cured cylinders cured the same as the concrete member when compressive strength is used to determine the curing period .
the curing period is the specified number of consecutive days when compressive strength is not used to determine the curing period .

specified curing methods apply to exposed concrete surfaces and any formed surfaces where the forms are removed before the curing period ends .
num fc specified num day minimum compressive strength .
num the curing period for bridge elements that use high early strength concrete may be reduced to the greater of num days and the time required to achieve the specified num day minimum compressive strength .
refer to section num for when the use of high early strength concrete is permitted .
num use a curing compound meeting astm cnum when removal is required .
implementation num concrete curing num page num of num january num num c. bridge decks and approach slabs num .
cure the exposed surfaces of newly placed concrete bridge decks and approach slabs for the specified curing period by a combination of the liquid membranecuring compound method and the water method .
num .
apply membranecuring compound so that no portion of the deck or approach slab is exposed to the atmosphere for more than num minutes after the tining or finishing operation .
a .
use a work bridge that follows immediately after the finishing machine to allow application of the curing compound while the concrete is still plastic .
num .
cover the entire exposed surface of bridge decks approach slabs curbs and sidewalks as soon as the concrete is sufficiently set to support the materials .
refer to this section article num for water method requirements .
d. concrete barrier num .
broom clean the formed surfaces of the barrier after removing forms .
num .
apply curing compound to exposed concrete surfaces immediately after finishing operations are completed .
num cure precast concrete a .
cure all formed surfaces using the fipm .
b .
cure exposed surfaces of newly placed precast concrete according to the curing methods and curing periods in table num .
num .

the curing period is the specified number of consecutive days when compressive strength is not used to determine the curing period .

us military specifications p. udot quality management plan num definitions a .
working force the force remaining in the prestressing steel after prestressing losses have either taken place or been provided for .
these losses include concrete creep and shrinkage concrete elastic compression steel creep and anchorage take ups .
b .
working stress the stress remaining in the prestressing steel after prestressing losses have either taken place or been provided for .
these losses include concrete creep and shrinkage concrete elastic compression steel creep and anchorage take ups .

num .

num .

a .

num handling storage and delivery a .

b .

num .

num .

num .

num .

equipment used to stress tendons must be accurate including jacks pressure gauges and load cells .

num .

a .
the range of the load cell must be so that the lower num percent of the manufacturers rated capacity is not used in determining the jacking stress .
num .
the prestressing force may be tested by the engineer .
num .

c. prestressing steel num .
