num .
protect against physical damage and corrosion during handling storing and shipping .
num .
replace prestressing steel that has damage loose rust pitting or serious corrosion .
a .
slight rusting is acceptable if it does not cause visible pits .
num .
do not oil or grease prestressing strand .
d. pretensioning num .
install and support testing equipment at the prestressing tendons and remove the testing equipment after the testing is completed .
num .
tension prestressing steel with hydraulic jacks so that the force in the prestressing steel is not less than the value shown .
num .

num .
maximum temporary tensile stress jacking stress in prestressing steel must not exceed num percent of the specified minimum ultimate tensile strength .
num .
anchor the prestressing steel at stresses initial stress that result in the ultimate retention of working forces not less than those shown .
num .
the stress loss in pretensioned prestressing steel due to concrete creep and shrinkage steel creep and concrete elastic compression is as shown .
num .

a .
use methods and equipment acceptable to engineer .

num .

num .

clean and paint the exposed strand ends and a num inch strip of adjoining concrete with zinc rich paint .
alternatively cut the strands at least num inch back from the girder end fill the recess with grout and finish flush with the girder ends .
a .
use a wire brush or abrasive blast cleaning to remove dirt and residue not firmly bonded to the metal or concrete surfaces .
b .
cover the surfaces with a thick application of zinc rich paint .
thoroughly mix the paint at the time of application and work it into voids in the strands .
c. apply two applications of zinc rich paint to surfaces that are not covered by concrete or mortar .

implementation num concrete slope protection repair num page num of num january num num b .

num .
place sealant when the ambient air temperature is at least num degrees f and rising .
num .
start the sealant placement at one side and proceed to the other side on horizontal grooves and from top to bottom on vertical joints .
num .
tool the sealant using a concave pointing tool with soap solution until the joints and recess are sealed over completely .
num .
finish sealant in a neat and clean fashion .
a. verify there are no irregular surfaces including peaks and valleys .
b .
remove sealant outside of the joint .

implementation num structural pothole patching num page num of num january num num num quality control a .
manufacturers technical representative num .
provide a technical representative from the structural pothole patching product manufacturer for training and consultation .
a .
provide training in surface preparation proper mixing placing and finishing technique safety precautions traffic opening time and environmental requirements .
num train workers who will mix place or finish the structural pothole patching product during production work in a preproduction meeting .
num use a mockup to demonstrate proper mixing placing and finishing technique .
num coordinate training with the engineer .
b .
the manufacturers technical representative must num be onsite during surface preparation and application of the structural pothole patching product on the initial structure and for the first day the structural pothole patching product is used on the project .
num be available for consultation but not necessarily present at the job site for the remaining work .
num be available to train workers who did not attend the preproduction training before they can perform production work .
num .
do not use workers for the production work who have not been trained by the manufacturers technical representative .
num .
the engineer may waive the requirement for the manufacturers technical representative to be onsite if the contractor can demonstrate that the superintendent for the work has performed at least five satisfactory applications of the structural pothole patching product on similar bridges in similar environments .
a .
the manufacturers technical representative must be available for consultation throughout the duration of the application .
num .
the department reserves the right to require the manufacturers technical representative to be onsite if at any time the engineer is concerned with the product installation quality .

num use num lb class jackhammer .

section num painting for structural steel num references a. aashto m num zinc hotdip galvanized coatings on iron and steel products b. aashto m num structural steel for bridges c. aashto lrfd bridge construction specifications d. aashto lrfd bridge design specifications e. aashtoaws dnum bridge welding code f. astm a num carbon steel alloy steel and stainless steel nuts for bolts for high pressure or high temperature service or both g. astm a num mechanical testing of steel products h. astm a num carbon and alloy steel nuts i. astm f num hardened steel washers j. astm f num determining the mechanical properties of externally and internally threaded fasteners washers direct tension indicators and rivets k. astm f num compressiblewashertype direct tension indicators for use with structural fasteners implementation num structural steel num page num of num january num num l. astm f num high strength structural bolts steel and alloy steel heat treated num ksi and num ksi minimum tensile strength m. american institute of steel construction aisc n. research council on structural connections rcsc o .
society for protective coatings sspc p. udot steel and concrete construction manual num definitions a .
main members members on a critical load path that carry bridge dead and live loads .
the loss of capacity of main members would have serious consequences on the structural integrity .
b .
secondary members members other than main members not designed to carry primary load .

num .

testing num .

implementation num structural steel num page num of num january num num c. install fasteners according to aashto lrfd bridge construction specifications section num the bolting procedure in the authorized erection drawings and the following num .

num .
use dti washers to indicate bolt tension .
a .
follow the manufacturers methods and procedures as modified by the engineer .
b .
place dti washer on the side of the connection that will not be embedded in concrete .
num a dti washer is still required if the entire fastener will be embedded in concrete .
num do not place concrete until the inspector has certified that all fasteners are properly tightened .
num .
use drift pins to align bolt holes and maintain dimensions and camber of the member .
num .
insert bolts in open holes with washers and hand tighten .
num .
tighten at least num percent of the fasteners as required to approximately onehalf final tension to draw all plies of the connection into firm contact .
a .
do not tighten any fasteners to indicated full tension at this time .
num .
remove drift pins and replace with bolts .
num .
tighten fasteners progressively from fixed or rigid points to the free edges .
num .
fully tighten num percent of the fasteners for field splices and diaphragms .
verify remaining fasteners are snug tight before release of crane or removal of shoring .
a .
reduce the dti washer gap to num inch regardless of which element is turned for tightening .
num .
tighten all fasteners to full tension .
num. review the dti washer compression for each fastener after the first connection .
a .
reevaluate tightening procedure and make corrections as required if over num percent of dti washers tested are fully compressed .

num erection a erector qualifications num .
an aisc certified erector with one of the following certifications is preferred when erecting bolting and welding bridge framing members a .
certified steel erector with bridge erection endorsement requirements criteria b .
advanced certified steel erector checklist criteria .
b .
maintain responsibility for girder erection during each stage of construction including the protection of structural steel members the workers and the traveling public .
c. erect structural steel members according to the authorized erection drawings and in a manner that prevents damage to elements of the structure .
num .
follow matchmarks .
d. temporarily support anchor and brace main members such as girders during erection to produce the proper alignment and camber in the completed structure .
num .
install cross frames and diagonal bracing as necessary to provide stability and correct geometry .
num .
provide temporary bracing or stiffening devices if necessary during each erection stage .
num .
support anchor and brace erected superstructure members as detailed in the authorized erection drawings before allowing traffic under the bridge .
implementation num structural steel num page num of num january num num e. design temporary supports and falsework according to the current edition of the aashto lrfd bridge construction specifications section num temporary works .
f. provide additional materials that are required to keep both the temporary and final stresses within the allowable limits used in design .
g. handle materials so that no parts will be bent broken or otherwise damaged .
num .
do not injure or distort the members when hammering .
h. remove dirt and debris from bearing surfaces and surfaces that will be in permanent contact before the members are assembled .
i .
do not open traffic under a partially erected bridge superstructure unless allowed in the authorized erection drawings .
end of section bolted field splice certification and bolted diaphragm connection certification forms follow .

compression joint seal a joint seal placed in compression before installation and kept in compression during its life .
num .
seals the joint as shown to prevent water from seeping through the joint .
b. elastomeric joint seal preformed open cell vulcanized elastomeric compound using virgin polychloroprene as the only polymer c. silicone coating factory applied external facing applied to the foam at a width greater than the maximum joint extension and cured before final compression .
d. type a open cell precompressed selfexpanding polyurethane foam with factory applied highwaygrade silicone joint seal .
e. type b preformed open cell vulcanized elastomeric joint seal .
f. watertight no free dripping water or patches of moisture on any surface under the joint .

num watertight integrity test a .
perform a watertight integrity test on the joint system at least five calendar days after the joint has been installed .
num .
test full width or staged width of the joint system as shown .
num .
perform the watertight integrity test in the presence of the engineer .
b. pond at least num inch of water over the joint for num minutes where num joints are over steel or concrete surfaces that can be inspected .
a .
inspect the steel and concrete surfaces for any evidence of dripping water or moisture for the initial num minutes and for num minutes after the ponded water has been released .
implementation num compression joint seal num page num of num january num num num .
joints are over steel or concrete surfaces that can not be inspected .
a .
measure and record the initial depth of the ponded water .
b .
measure and record the depth of the ponded water after num minutes .
c. the test can be stopped if depth of ponded water has not changed num inch or more .
d. continue the test for an additional num minutes if depth of water has changed more than num inch .
num measure and record the depth of the ponded water .
num the test is considered a failure if the water level has changed by an additional num inch or more .
c. locate the places in the joint system where leakage is occurring and take measures necessary to stop the leakage .
num .
submit a repair procedure recommended by the manufacturer .
num .
repair joint system according to the authorized manufacturers recommended repair procedure .
num .
repeat watertight integrity test .

c. joints and cracks num .

implementation num waterproofing membrane num page num of num january num num num apply membrane a. rubberized asphalt membrane follow membrane manufacturers recommendations for application temperatures equipment and procedures .
num .
primer a .
use primer furnished by the manufacturer of membrane material .
b .
apply primer to all surfaces to be covered by the membrane according to the manufacturers recommended procedure and application rate .
num .
placement a .
overlap prefabricated membrane strips at least num inches or as required by the manufacturer .
b .
place joints in a shingling effect so water will drain effectively .
num .
bonding a .
use hand rollers or other satisfactory pressure apparatus on the membrane to assure firm and uniform contact with the primed surfaces .
b .
use a wide tipped torch to cause tackiness if an adhesive is required to create a good seal at joints .
num .
placement a .
place the membrane on the vertical face of the concrete curb to the height of the finished overlay surfacing plus num inch .
num .
defects a .
protect the entire membrane from developing wrinkles air bubbles or other placement defects .
b. patch any torn or cut areas and narrow overlaps using a satisfactory adhesive and a piece of membrane .
c. extend the patch at least num inches beyond any defect .
d. bond the patch firmly to the surface .
num .
traffic a .
allow only necessary rubber tire vehicles on the membrane .
b .
do not allow public traffic .
c. maintain the membrane in good condition until covered with pavement .
num .
preparation for overlaying a .
apply a bond coat of an acceptable adhesive to the surface of the membrane if required by the membrane manufacturer .

b .

num .

table num backer rod properties physical property requirement density num lbftnum minimum tensile strength num psi minimum compression num psi at num minimum water absorption num gcmnum by weight minimum num maximum temperature at num f no melting b .

part num execution num groove joint and crack locations a .
mark the limits of all grooves joints and cracks in the presence of the engineer .
this applies to all grooves joints and cracks that require sealing .
num .
seal cracks num inch and larger .
num prepare grooves joints and cracks a .
remove the existing joint or groove material and all other debris from the designated grooves joints and cracks .
remove curing compounds oil grease dirt moisture and any other foreign materials from the groove joint or cracked concrete surfaces by sandblasting .
num seal grooves joints and cracks a .
use a backer rod when the joint width is equal to or greater than  inch .
b. seal the grooves joints and cracks as field marked .
c. seal horizontal grooves joints and cracks by starting at one side and proceed to the other side .
implementation num sealing existing concrete slope protection joints num page num of num january num num d. seal vertical grooves joints and cracks from the top to bottom .
num seal wingwalls and backwall joints a .
place the rigid plastic foam against the surface of all structural members before placing the joint sealant .
b. anchor the rigid plastic foam in place with a compatible adhesive .
c. recess the rigid plastic foam  inch in the joints so a groove is formed above the rigid plastic foam filler .
d. fill the recess above the rigid plastic foam with sealant so the joint is sealed over completely .
num place sealant a .
place with a hand or power operated caulking gun after placing the backer rod .
b .
tool the sealant using a concave pointing tool with soap solution .

num .

detector loop circuit conduct the following acceptance tests before and after backfill for approval by the engineer .
num .
measure and report in ohms the continuity of each loop .
num .
value to be within num percent of calculated values .
num .
loop resistance formula rt rl rd .
where rt resistance of loop as measured at pull box .
rl resistance of loop lead in wire from the loop to junction box .
equal to num ohms per foot times num measured from loop to pull box splice point .
rd resistance of loop ptrc see loop resistance table below .
p perimeter of loop in feet .
t number of turns in the loop .
rc resistance of num awg copper wire per foot equals num ohms .

a .

num .
measure and report the inductance of each loop .
a .
acceptable inductance readings are greater than num h for individual loops and less than num h for a num loop group .

national electrical code nec c. telcordia guidance d. underwriters laboratory ul e. usda rural utilities service rus num definitions a .
backbone cable that connects two buildings or a building to a hubnode b .
drop cable that originates at a distribution splice interface cabinet or device and terminates at or links served devices .
c. fiber distribution unit fdu a storage and management box for use in cabinets and communication hubs for the terminated ends and splice points of the fiber optic cable .
d. full splice a splice that has had all fibers spliced .
e. ring cut splice a splice where only selected fibers are severed and others remain intact .

use the following minimum lubricant quantity for each cable pull q num d l where q the quantity of lubricant gallons d the diameter of the conduit inches l the length of the pull feet f. use shear pins or other failsafe means to prevent exceeding the maximum cable pulling tension as rated by the cable manufacturer .

num test all fibers both within the trunk cable and the drop cable .
b .
conduct all traces with a launch cable or fiber test box between the otdr and the fiber under test .
c. do not exceed insertion loss num db .
d. conduct all traces at both num nm and num nm .
e. provide traces with the following information num horizontal axis distance in feet .
num vertical axis attenuation scale in db .
num traces showing attenuation versus distance .
num cursors positioned at cable ends .

g. provide an event table showing all events with more than num db loss containing event type position from otdr end loss and reflectance .
h. the maximum total allowable attenuation is num db for cables less than num ft num km in length .
i .
identify fibers by strand number .
j .

l. cover sheets are required for final test results with reviewers signature date and a statement indicating the installation complies with the requirements of this section .

num related sections a .
section num precast concrete fiber optic and utility vault b .
section num atms conduit c. section num polymer concrete junction box d. section num fiber optic communication e. section num electrical power num references not used num definitions a .
integration the process of enabling the completed atms device to function as intended .
this includes but may not be limited to connecting all items such as required communication control and power cables entering all required device parameters aiming devices such as antennas calibrating or adjusting devices enabling communication to the device from the toc and completing all specified tests to verify that integration is complete .

num inspection and testing a .

implementation num atms integration inspection testing and acceptance num page num of num january num num num .

num .

table num atms testing and acceptance process matrix required test prerequisites description punch list from engineers site inspection esi complete and submit at the time of the engineers site inspection esi .
include on the esi punch list items that must be completed or adjusted before any part of a device or system installation is energized .
num day atms testing pre notification submit num days in advance of proposed test dates test form to the engineer num days before each test or inspection that must be witnessed by the department or authorized representative .
atms cable and conductor test basic construction of conduits boxes wiring and cabinets .
perform this test after wire has been pulled but before devices are energized the atms cable and conductor test is used to confirm that cable is not faulty and has not been damaged during installation engineers site inspection esi receipt of all required submittals as noted in sections num num num num num and completion of basic construction elements the esi is used to confirm that the device or system has been constructed according to the project requirements and is ready to be energized and begin the integration process .
the esi will note any obvious issues with wiring configuration incorrect inventory differences from project plans or general cleanliness of the site .
local field operations test lfot successful completion of local configuration and integration as well as completion of operational punch list items from the esi the lfot is used to confirm that the device or system has been configured and integrated according to the project requirements and is ready to be tested centrally .
systems test if required successful completion of lfot and integration of device to central toc control project specific by special provision .
certain projects or types of devices may require a complete system test where multiple elements applications or devices are tested simultaneously implementation num atms integration inspection testing and acceptance num page num of num january num num atms testing and acceptance process matrix required test prerequisites description substantial completion inspection sci successful completion of the lfot successful integration of device to the traffic operations center active central communications to device the sci is used to confirm that the atms device subsystem or system meets the operational parameters described within the project plans specifications and special provisions .
the contractor must demonstrate the remote device sites communicate to the toc and operate as a single integrated system as required in the project requirements in addition to having all construction and integration tasks completed .
the system will be considered substantially complete and may begin the num day atms burnin period with the successful completion of this inspection and testing .
num day atms burnin period successful substantial completion inspection and submission of the num day atms burnin test form .
the num day atms burnin period confirms that the atms device or system was properly constructed and integrated .
acceptance satisfactory completion of the num day burnin test completion of all items on the engineers site inspection punch list and submittal of approved as built drawings .
acceptance transfers ownership of the system or devices to the department .
at that point the warranty begins and the ownership and maintenance of the site or system transfers to the department .
written notification from the department to the contractor is required for final acceptance to occur .
construction asbuilt drawings within num days after the num day atms burn in test .
asbuilt drawings will be reviewed verified and accepted before final device or system acceptance .
asbuilt drawings of each atms device installation showing actual locations of all installed conduit boxes and cabinets and any differences in construction from plans .

implementation num atms integration inspection testing and acceptance num page num of num january num num num .
perform a diagnostic test in the event that an equipment failure occurs .
a .
respond and conduct diagnostic test within num hours of notification by the engineer .
b .
the burnin test will be suspended during diagnostic testing .
num .
complete all necessary work to correct the problem within num hours of notification unless the engineer allows additional time .
num .
submit equipment failure report to the engineer within num hours after notification of the problem .
a .
fully describe the problem its cause and all actions taken to rectify the failure .
b .

c. meet the operational requirements and project specifications for all equipment or modules used in the replacement or repair subject to the full testing process .
num .

a .
replace malfunctioning electrical or electronic equipment will in kind .
num .

num preparation a .

num trenching and directional boring for conduit a. trenching paved asphalt surface num .
do not use backhoe .
num .
make the trench num inches wide or less .
num .
use flowable fill to within num inches of the existing roadway surface unless otherwise specified .
num .
apply tack coat evenly before final backfill when placing hma .
num .
match the composition density and elevation within num inch of the existing pavement section .
b. trenching unpaved surface num .
use backfill that matches the composition density and elevation within num inch of the existing surface .
num .
install conduits that cross finished curbs and gutters sidewalks concrete flatwork textured or decorative surfaces by jacking drilling or pushing .
num .
dispose of surplus material promptly .

traffic signals a .
refer to sl series standard drawings .
num .
all others a .
refer to at series standard drawings .
b .
refer to utah administrative rule num d. directional boring num .
directional boring is an approved alternative to trenching unless otherwise specified .
num .

implementation num electrical power num page num of num january num num num install conduit a .
use rigid metal conduit or schedule num pvc conduit for above ground application .
num .
liquidtight flexible metal conduit or liquidtight flexible non metallic conduit is permitted in lengths not exceeding num ft where not subject to physical damage .
num .
apply corrosion protection to any portion of rigid metal conduit buried in the ground or encased in concrete .
b .
use pvc or hdpe conduit for underground application .
c. install a bushing or bell end adapter at ends of all conduit .
d. seal uncapped conduit ends inside junction box num .
conduit num inches and smaller seal with at least num inches of duct caulking or pvc cap .
num .
conduit larger than num inches seal with duct plug or pvc cap .
e. do not use a torch for bending or shaping pvc conduit .
num .
use equipment specifically designed to heat pvc conduit to shape any required curves or radii .
f. use couplers specifically designed to couple pvc conduit to hdpe conduit .
g. install weatherproof junction box with breakaway receptacle or fuse holder at breakaway structures .
h. do not exceed num degrees of conduit sweeps between individual junction boxes .
i .
route conduit entering junction boxes to enter on the narrow side at an angle perpendicular to the box .
num .
run conduit to the junction box by the most direct route using the fewest bends possible .
implementation num electrical power num page num of num january num num num install conductors a. verify conduit is clean dry and free of dirt and debris before installing conductors .
b .
use conductor manufacturer approved pulling compound or lubricant where necessary .
num .
compound used must not deteriorate conductor or insulation .
c. do not exceed manufacturers recommended maximum pulling tensions .
d. install equipment grounding conductor in all conduits .
num .
copper grounding conductors must run continuously between and be bonded to ground rods in each junction box .
num .
aluminum grounding conductors must run continuously between junction boxes and be bonded to the ground rod in each junction box using a num inch insulated copper pigtail conductor .
a .
match copper pigtail gauge to aluminum grounding conductor gauge .
e. install conductors from source to load in continuous lengths without splicing .
f. terminate conductors .
num .
use wet location connectors in wet locations including all underground and inground locations .
num .
dry location twist type connectors may be used in dry above ground locations .
num .
do not use vinyl electrical tape as the sole means of insulating a connection or connector .
g. identify each conductor by circuit phase voltage source and load .
num .
conductors num awg and smaller must have continuous outer insulation color complying with nec requirements .
num .
conductors num awg and larger may be identified by use of colored phase tape at all junction boxes and terminations .
num .
group all conductors of each circuit using wrap around or flag type cable markers .
a .
identify source and load location by description and milepost .
b .
do not use station numbers to describe location .
h. leave num ft of slack conductor measured from the opening of each junction box that the conductor passes through .
implementation num electrical power num page num of num january num num i .
make aluminum conductor connections in accordance with neca num .
j .
neatly arrange and support conductors within cabinets junction boxes and fixtures .
num grounding and bonding a .
bond equipment grounding conductors to ground rods metal equipment enclosures metal poles and ground busses .
num .
comply with nec article num requirements .
b .
bond neutral conductors to metal equipment enclosures and equipment grounding conductors only at electrical service equipment and at transformer secondary terminals and other separately derived systems .
num .
comply with nec article num requirements .
c. install concrete encased electrodes where shown and as required by the nec .
bond existing concrete encased electrodes such as pole anchor bolts to metal pole or equipment enclosures and equipment grounding conductor .
num .
concrete encased electrode consists of conductive metal in structure foundation encased by at least num inches of concrete where foundation is in direct contact with the earth .
use one of the following conductive metal elements a .
num awg bare copper conductor num ft minimum length .
b. bare or zinc galvanized steel reinforcing bars or anchor bolts num inch minimum diameter num ft total length .
num connect lengths of bar together with steel tie wires to meet total length requirement .
num epoxy coated reinforcing bar may not be used as part of the grounding electrode .
c. no additional conductive metal is required in the concrete foundation where anchor bolts or other conductive metal satisfies requirements above .
d. install ground rods where shown and as required by the nec .
num .
drive ground rods until tops are num inches below final grade at services and separately derived systems .
num .
install ground rod to extend a minimum of num inches and a maximum of num inches above box floor in junction boxes .
num .
space ground rods minimum of num feet apart where multiple rods are shown or are required by the nec .
num .
provide num inch copper jumper from ground rod to aluminum equipment grounding conductor .

install equipment level and plumb .

b .

c. close and seal any unused openings .
d. install fuses in fusible devices .

num testing a .
after installation but before terminating test each conductor for insulation integrity to adjacent conductors and ground using numvdc megohmmeter .
num .
record insulation resistance in megohms after num seconds and num seconds rnum and rnum .
num .
calculate polarization index by dividing the num second resistance by the num second resistance rnum rnum .
num .
replace any conductors with a polarization index value less than num .
b .
measure transformer secondary voltage while loaded to final load and record voltage and submit for information .
c. record insulation test resistance values polarization index and transformer voltage measurements and submit for information .
